revision.comment: Removing "Pharmedout.jpg", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Steinsplitter|Steinsplitter]] because: No license since 2014-05-04. Please read the intro of [[commons:COM:L]], about [[commons:Commons:Essential information|essential inform...
revision.text:
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ghostwriter Medical ghostwriting] is a covert practice among the medical community by which the authors who significantly contribute to medical literature are not given credit, and the authors listed have not substantially contributed to the paper.
==Introduction== Medical ghostwriting typically involves the use of hired writers from marketing companies to write research papers based on data provided from pharmaceutical companies. These hired authors are not given actual credit on the paper. Instead, credit is given to a respected researcher or physician in the field who has little or no involvement in the research or writing process. This practice appears to be primarily used by larger pharmaceutical companies seeking to strategically use these published medical papers to promote the use of their products.
==The Ghostwriting Culture== Ghostwriting's presence in the medical industry can be largely attributed to an ambivalent culture that does little to prevent it. There are four major participants in the ghostwriting industry. Ghostwriters are the true authors behind many medical research papers. Honorary authors are the medical professionals who sign their name to papers despite having minimal participation in the paper's creation. The pharmaceutical industry hires the ghostwriters and recruits the honorary authors for these papers. And ultimately medical journals receive these papers to be published.
===Ghostwriter's Perspective=== {{Rquote|right| '''I believe that many of the factors that kept me in medical writing apply to most medical writers... I believed that I was helping people: sick people need drugs, and physicians need to know about those drugs to prescribe them appropriately.'''| Linda Lodgberg, a ghostwriter<ref name="linda">Logdberg, L. (2011, August 9). Being the Ghost in the Machine: A Medical Ghostwriter's Personal View. PLoS Med. 8(8), e1001071.</ref>}}
The ghostwriters often view themselves as someone who is simply helping a researcher get their papers published quickly and in the best journals. One writer remarks, "I believe I provide a service to those who need assistance presenting their findings to the scientific community. If you have a great study but present it badly you won’t be seeing it anytime soon in NEJM."<ref>Davis, P. (2010, October 29). Interview With a Ghost (Writer). The Scholarly Kitchen.. Retrieved from http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2010/10/29/interview-with-a-ghost-writer/</ref> It is also viewed by some as an honorable job because they can write better than researchers and these papers will eventually be used to help people.
===Honorary Author's Perspective=== Honorary authors are often asked by pharmaceutical companies to simply attach their name to ghostwritten papers, but this is not the only method used. Sometimes these authors are asked to be research consultants, leading to unaware physicians attaching their names to papers they had nothing to do with.<ref name="Gaidos">Gaidos, S. (2010, Nov 12). Ghostwriters in the Medical Literature. Retrieved from http://sciencecareers.sciencemag.org/career_magazine/previous_issues/articles/2010_11_12/caredit.a1000110</ref>
Many honorary authors attach their names to ghostwritten papers for authorship credit. In the research community it is very important to have published papers, and in some cases, researchers have a quota of papers they need to reach. As a result, some researchers are willing to attach their names to papers they had little to do with.
There is also a lack of strict guidelines on how to handle ghost-authorship in many medical research communities. The ultimate effect is a culture that sees ghostwriting as something common, and accepted.
:''“The section on ghostwriting in WAME's code of ethics was "fairly thin and not very explicit," ... it was unclear that it would cover this type of authorship. There wasn't anything that specifically addressed the relationship between pharmaceutical industry's medical-education companies and ghost authorship.” -Martha Gerrity, co-editor of the Journal of General Internal Medicine''<ref name="Gaidos" />
===Pharmaceutical Company's Perspective=== Pharmaceutical companies see research papers not just as a tool to disseminate information, but also as a means to advertise a drug they want to sell on the market. Ghostwriters are told to write in a way that favors the company's product, "My job was to draft a monograph that would profile the product's benefits, one of which, according to the client, was that although the bleeding could be severe, it was at least something that women could anticipate."<ref name="linda" /> Pharmaceutical companies also frequently attempt to publish many papers about the same research but with different honorary authors, making the case for using their drug even stronger. <ref>Fugh-Berman, A. (2013, November 19). How Basic Scientists Help the Pharmaceutical Industry Market Drugs. PLoS Biol. 11(11), e1001716</ref> See [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Marketing_of_Pharmaceuticals Marketing of pharmaceuticals]for more information.
===Journal's Perspective=== Historically journals have been lax on ghostwriting guidelines, partially leading to ghostwriting's current prevalence. Most medical journals lack specific rules on ghostwriting.<ref>Seaman, S. (2013, April 9). Many medical journals lack ghostwriting policies. Reuters. Retrieved from http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/us-health-ghostwriting-idUSBRE93813720130409</ref> However, journals are starting to adopt stricter standards for what they allow and what constitutes ghostwriting. "More than 600 biomedical journals have adopted guidelines for responsible and accountable authorship " <ref>Preidt, R. (2011, October 6). Ghost Writing Persists in Major Medical Journals. HealthDay. Retrieved from http://consumer.healthday.com/general-health-information-16/miscellaneous-479/ghost-writing-persists-in-major-medical-journals-658178.html</ref> Journals that do claim to have strict guidelines on authorship place the blame on the authors. The chief editor of PLoS Medicine, Ginny Barbour, claimed, “we are a journal that has very tough policies, very explicit policies on ghostwriting and contributorship, and I feel that we’ve basically been lied to by authors.” <ref>Wilson, D. & Singer, S. (2009, September 10). Ghostwriting Is Called Rife in Medical Journals. The New York Times. Retrieved from http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/business/11ghost.html?_r=0 </ref> In general, journals treat ghostwriting as a problem of the authors rather than a problem with their own standards.
==What Makes an Author== The International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) considers authorship based on four criteria: * Substantial contributions to the conception or design of the work; or the acquisition, analysis, or interpretation of data for the work * Drafting the work or revising it critically for important intellectual content * Final approval of the version to be published * Agreement to be accountable for all aspects of the work in ensuring that questions related to the accuracy or integrity of any part of the work are appropriately investigated and resolved<ref>ICMJE (International Committee of Medical Journal Editors). Defining the Role of Authors and Contributors. Retrieved from http://www.icmje.org/recommendations/browse/roles-and-responsibilities/defining-the-role-of-authors-and-contributors.html</ref> An author should meet all four criteria to have their name placed on the paper, otherwise they should just be acknowledged in the paper. All authors must be able to identify the contributions of each of their co-authors, and should be confident in the integrity of each co-author.
===Authorship Requirements Among Top Medical Journals=== [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_(journal) ''Science''] requires that all authors of a manuscript are listed, and have seen and approved the manuscript, its content and its submission to the journal.<ref>Science. General Information for Authors. Retrieved from http://www.sciencemag.org/site/feature/contribinfo/prep/gen_info.xhtml#authorship</ref> Any changes made must be approved by all authors. Also, authors must be able to explain their contributions to the manuscript. ''Science'' also requires that all funding sources and affiliations of the authors are noted so there is no source of bias.
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nature_(journal) ''Nature''] journals do not require all authors to sign the letter of submission.<ref>Nature. Authorship. Retrieved from http://www.nature.com/authors/policies/authorship.html</ref> Changes to the author list need to be approved by a letter signed by all authors. In the manuscript, authors need to write a statement outlining the contributions of each author. The senior member of the group needs to accept responsibility for the author's contributions, as well as making sure that the data used is preserved and retrievable.
The [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Journal_of_Medicine ''New England Journal of Medicine''] (NEJM) follows the criteria stated by the ICMJE.<ref> The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM). Author Center New Manuscripts. Retrieved from http://www.nejm.org/page/author-center/manuscript-submission#authorship</ref> Authors must sign a statement attesting that they fulfill the requirements. Also, any change in authorship must be approved by all authors.
==Comparisons to plagiarism== The concept of ghostwriting is essentially [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism plagiarism]. Scientists are putting their name on articles they did not write. If students did this it would be considered plagiarism. However, the comparison isn't black and white.<ref>iThenticate. Can ghostwriting be considered plagiarism? Retrieved from http://www.ithenticate.com/plagiarism-detection-blog/bid/64034/Can-Ghostwriting-Be-Considered-Plagiarism#.U2aKR_ldWSo</ref> Some ghostwriters participate in the entire writing process, researching, writing and editing the paper. Some will only write while some will solely edit. Some ghostwriters do get acknowledged by the authors while others remain completely anonymous. The comparison comes down to what medical journals consider when proper and legal consent was given to leave the ghostwriters name off the manuscript.
==Case Study: Adriane Fugh-Berman==
Adriane Fugh-Berman is an Associate Professor of Pharmacology and Physiology at the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgetown_University_Medical_Center Georgetown University Medical Center], and an expert of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbalism botanical medicine] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietary_supplement dietary supplements].<ref>Georgetown University. Adriane J Fugh-Berman. Retrieved from http://explore.georgetown.edu/people/ajf29/</ref> In 2004 she was asked by a medical education and communications company to author a review article about the interactions of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warfarin warfarin], an [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anticoagulant anticoagulant], with herbs. The invitation mentioned that the study was funded by a drug company, which to Fugh-Berman had no clear link to the drug or herbal products. She asked for more information about the company, and heard nothing back until August 24, 2004 when she received a completed draft of the article with her name on the cover page. The marketing company requested that she review the article and return any comments or changes she wanted to make. She was also informed that the sponsoring company had a drug that would compete with warfarin, and wanted to prime the market for the arrival of their new drug. <ref name="Corporate">Fugh-Berman, A. (2005, June). The Corporate Coauthor. J Gen Intern Med. 20(6), 546-48</ref> ===The Corporate Coauthor=== Fugh-Berman responded to this company's request with an emphatic no, and reminded herself to keep an eye out for this article. However, a few months later the article ended up on her desk again, but this time she was being asked to peer-review it for the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_General_Internal_Medicine ''Journal of General Internal Medicine'']. She immediately notified the journal's editors that this article had been ghostwritten, and urged the editors not to publish it. The journal complied, and instead published an article written by Fugh-Berman, [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1490131/ ''The Corporate Coauthor'']. This article was one of the first exposés on the medical ghostwriting culture.<ref name="Gaidos" /> It describes her interactions with the marketing company and exposed the process by which honorary authors are asked to be authors of such papers. Fugh-Berman endorses two methods to combat ghostwriting. First, journals should follow the example of the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Family_Physician ''American Family Physician''], which requires authors to fill out a questionnaire with specific situations to determine conflicts of interest.<ref>Fugh-Berman, A., Siwek, J. (2011, September 1). Compromising the Medical Literature: The Hidden Influence of Industry - Biased Articles. Am Fam Physician. 84(5), 489-91.</ref> With this system authors have to actively lie to hide an unacknowledged author, "You can lie, but you can't say that you didn't understand the question. And I think that that's important. ... You don't want people deciding for themselves what are relevant conflicts of interest because nobody thinks their conflicts of interest are relevant."<ref name="Gaidos" /> Second, Fugh-Berman advocates a public database that contains known conflicts of interest and ethical transgressions of authors. This database could then be used by medical journals when trying to determine if an article is ghostwritten or has a corporate sponsor.<ref name="Corporate" />
===Pharmed Out===
In 2006 Adriane Fugh-Berman helped to found an advocacy group called [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PharmedOut ''PharmedOut'']. The mission of this organization is to advance evidence-based prescribing of drugs and to encourage physicians to choose unbiased sources for [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuing_medical_education continued medical education]. PharmedOut has published several articles that highlight marketing methods that pharmaceutical companies used to influence prescribing, and hosts an annual concert to discuss the role of the pharmaceutical industry in the medical community.<ref>PharmedOut. Retrieved from http://www.pharmedout.org/</ref>
==Other Cases of Medical Ghostwriting==
===Woo Suk Hwang=== Dr. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hwang_Woo-suk Woo Suk Hwang], a South Korean scientist was linked to a paper with fraudulent authorship.<ref>Strange, K. (2008, September). Authorship: why not just flip a coin?. Am J Physiol Cell Physiol. 295(3), C567-75.</ref> In the two papers Hwang published in ''Science'' it was found that the data had been fabricated and thus the papers were retracted. A coauthor on this paper, Dr. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_Schatten Gerald Schatten], a scientist from the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_School_of_Medicine University of Pittsburgh] tried to clear his name from this scandal, but was found guilty of "scientific misbehavior." He confirmed that he had helped write the manuscript, but didn't participate in the data collection and was rarely in contact with the other scientists. Investigators concluded that Schatten deserved credit for being an author, however assuming senior authorship was a mistake. By putting his name on this paper, Schatten enhanced his reputation and received substantial personal financial benefit in the short-term. But Schatten neglected his responsibilities of maintaining the integrity of the paper and assuming that all coauthors approved the manuscript for submission, and this came back to hurt him in the long-run.
==Theory of Beneficial Skepticism== The Theory of Beneficial Skepticism is the general lesson that Adriane Fugh-Berman can teach about what it means to be a professional. It is impossible to prepare for every situation that will occur in a professional setting. Fugh-Berman had never been asked to be an honorary author before the warfarin-herb case in 2004, so she was not familiar with the methods and motivations of the medical education and communications companies. However, when approached she dealt with the situation as a skeptic. She asked for more information about the drug company and their reason for sponsoring the article, and refused to respond until she received a satisfactory response. Fugh-Berman teaches us that approaching unfamiliar situations with skepticism allows us to discern the underlying motivations of participants and to make informed ethical decisions.
==References== {{reflist}}

=Turkey= * Other than one meter used for a short time in 1937, postage meter use in Turkey began in 1954. * All franks contain “TÜRK POSTALARI” or “TÜRKIYE CUMHURIYETI”. * The stamps are grouped according to appearance: :: A – Frank with scalloped single-line frame line :: B – Frank with simulated-perforation outer frame line and straight inner frame line :: C – Franks with straight frame lines along all sides :: D – Frank without outer frame line and with town mark attached :: E – Frank with frame lines at top and bottom only, top line always with indented semi-circles :: F – Frank with frame lines at top and bottom only, top line always straight '''NOTE''': For more detailed information about the meter stamps of Turkey, see ''Die Absender- und Postfreistempel der Türkei'', by Otto Gleixner, self-published 1995, Seefeld, Germany.
---- ==GROUP A: Small upright frank with scalloped single-line outer border==
[[File: Turkey stamp type A1.jpg|left|480px]]
'''A1. Francotyp “C” ''' (MV), 1937. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$200] : Star and Crescent in circle at top, “TÜRK POSTALARI” at bottom. : Only about ten examples known. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 ---- ==GROUP B: Double frame lines with simulated-perforation outer border and straight-line inner border==
---- ====SUB-GROUP BA: Star and crescent in field at right center==== ----
[[File: Turkey stamp type BA1A.jpg|left|370px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA1B.jpg|left|370px]]

'''BA1. Universal “MultiValue” ''' (MV), 1954. : Nearly square frank inscribed “KURUS” above boxed “POSTALARI” at bottom. : Text in frank is sanserif. : Star and crescent face left towards the center of the frank. :::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Large crescent, 9 mm tall [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] :::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Small crescent, 6.5 mm tall : TM: SC, DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000(½)[[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA2.jpg|left|370px]]
'''BA2. Universal “MultiValue” ''' (MV). : As Type BA1B but text in frank with serifs. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 :::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Printed in black [[File: image needed.jpg|left|170px]]
'''BA3. Universal “MultiValue” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : As Type BA1 but crescent faces right towards the outside of the frank. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA4A.jpg|left|505px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA4Ca.jpg|right|320px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA4B.jpg|left|490px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA4Cb.jpg|right|320px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA4Cc.jpg|right|320px]] '''BA4. Postalia''' (MV), 1955. : Frank smaller than Types BA1 and 2, and value figures small and narrow. : Star and crescent face left towards the center of the frank. :::::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Wide spacing between TM and frank. Large crescent 9 mm tall. Right frame line stops at star and crescent field :::::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Wide spacing between TM and frank. Small crescent 6 mm tall. Right frame line turns inward at star and crescent field :::::::::::::::::::::::: '''Ca'''. Narrow spacing between TM and frank, crescent field 11 x 10.5 mm with 13 lines :::::::::::::::::::::::: '''Cb'''. As "Ca", crescent field 9 x 10.5 mm with 13 lines :::::::::::::::::::::::: '''Cc'''. As "Ca" and "Cb", crescent field 9 x 9 mm with 10 or 11 lines ::::::::::::::::::::::: TM: DC, SC ::::::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA5.jpg|left|320px]]

'''BA5. Postalia''' (MV). : As Type BA4Cc but the star and crescent face right. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA6.jpg|left|320px]]
'''BA6. Postalia''' (MV). : As Type BA5 “LIRA” at lower left above “POSTALARI” unboxed. : Crescent faces right. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA7.jpg|left|320px]]
'''BA7. Postalia''' (MV). : Similar to Types BA5 and BA6 but with narrow field of dashes added left of the value figures. : “LIRA” is centered above boxed “POSTALARI”. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA8.jpg|left|360px]] '''BA8. Pitney Bowes-GB “Automax” ''' (MV), 1966. : Square frank wider than previous BA types. : “KURUS” above boxed “POSTALARI” at bottom. : Crescent faces left. : M# with “P.B.” prefix below frank. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=0000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA9A.jpg|left|330px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BA9B.jpg|left|340px]]

'''BA9. Francotyp “Cc” ''' (MV), 1967. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : “KURUS” above boxed “POSTALARI” at bottom. : Crescent faces center of frank. ::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Narrow frank, 24 x 30 mm ::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Wide frank, 28 x 30 mm : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]◆000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BA10.jpg|left|310px]]
'''BA10. Francotyp “Cc” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : As Type BA9 but Crescent faces right. : “LIRA” centered above boxed “POSTALARI” at bottom. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000 ---- ====SUB-GROUP BB: Star and crescent in field at left center====
----
[[File: Turkey stamp type BB1.jpg|left|300px]] '''BB1. Postalia''' (MV). : Tall, narrow frank : Small crescent faces right into center of frank. ::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Wide spacing between TM and frank (''not shown'')[[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] ::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Narrow spacing : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BB2.jpg|left|325px]] '''BB2. Pitney Bowes-GB “Automax” ''' (MV), 1986. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Large, square frank. : Crescent faces right into center of frank. : With “LIRA” above boxed “POSTALARI” at bottom. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=0000 ---- ====SUB-GROUP BC: Star and crescent in field at top right ====
----
[[File: Turkey stamp type BC1.jpg|left|400px]] '''BC1. Sima''' (MV), 1971. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Frank 26 x 29 mm. : Wide spacing between TM and frank. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BC2A.jpg|left|320px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type BC2B.jpg|left|320px]]
'''BC2. Satas “Rotary” ''' (MV), 1961. : Frank similar to Type BC1 but smaller. : Medium spacing between TM and frank. : Date figures tall or short. :::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Frank 23-24 x 25-26 mm :::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Frank 25 x 27 mm. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★000 :::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With hour figure between TM and frank :::::::::::::::: '''b'''. With backwards “F” symbol left of value figures [[File: Turkey stamp type BC3.jpg|left|300px]] '''BC3. Satas “Baby” ''' (MV), 1965. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : As Type BC2 but even smaller, 21 x 25 mm. : Date figures large. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★00 ---- ====SUB-GROUP BD: Without star and crescent====
----
[[File: Turkey stamp type BD1.jpg|left|330px]]
'''BD1. Postalia''' (MV), 1989. : “LIRA” in field at right center. : “POSTA” alone at bottom. : TM: DC, BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Turkey stamp type BD2.jpg|left|320px]]
'''BD2. Postalia''' (MV), 1986. : Similar to Tytpe BD1 but narrow field at right containing only lines. : “LIRA” centered above “POSTA” at bottom. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000000 ---- ==GROUP C: Frank with straight frame lines at all sides==

'''C1. Postalia''' (MV). : Upright frank with large panels at top and bottom. : Country name in top panel, "POSTA" in bottom panel. ::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Fixed zero and “LIRA” centered in line field at right ::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Two fixed zeros above “LIRA” in line field at right : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000000 [[File: Turkey stamp type C2.jpg|left|355px]] '''C2. Hasler “Mailmaster” ''' (MV). : Very wide frank. : "LIRA" imbedded in lines at right of value figures. : Without M#. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000+0 [[File: Turkey stamp type C3A.jpg|left|350px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type C3B.jpg|left|350px]]
'''C3. Neopost “Electronic” ''' (MV). : Square to slightly wide frank with panels at top and bottom. : Side frame lines open opposite top panel. : Country name at top, "POSTA" at bottom. ::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. "LIRA" below one fixed zero at right ::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. “LIRA” below three fixed zeros at right : Without M#. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋000 (+fixed zeros) [[File: Turkey stamp type C4.jpg|left|540px]] '''C4'''. Unidentified, probably Neopost (digital). : Frank wider than tall. : Value figures near bottom of frank with large "Kr" at right. : Time of day above date inside the TM. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 '''NOTE''': This may be a Post Office stamp. ---- ==GROUP D: Town mark and frank joined, without outer border==
[[File: Turkey stamp type D1.jpg|left|270px]] [[File: Turkey stamp type D1 NOTE.jpg|right|290px]] '''D1. Pitney Bowes “R” ''' (MV), 1959 or earlier. '''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.

== [[Professionalism/Medical Ghostwriting]] == This page has been queried because it contains no content. There is no need to create empty pages in Wikibooks. Leaving red links is fine - often better - because that way users can see that a page hasn't been started yet. If the page isn't developed further it may be deleted within 7 days.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 14:17, 20 April 2014 (UTC)

== Name == News::NAAF::ReadOnly – read-only access to NAAF streams == Synopsis == require News::NAAF::ReadOnly; my $ro = News::NAAF::ReadOnly->new ($filehandle, { }); my $naaf_header = $ro->header (); my $naaf_trailer = $ro->trailer (); my $article = $ro->article (42); my $connection = $ro->connection (3); my $group = $ro->group (7); $ro->close (); == Description == The News::NAAF::ReadOnly module provides read-only access to NAAF streams. The interface implemented is rather high-level; the instances can be directly queried for specific NAAF objects (including NAAF stream [[../News::NAAF::NAAFHeader|header]] and [[../News::NAAF::NAAFTrailer|trailer]] records, specific netnews [[../News::NAAF::Article|articles]] and [[../News::NAAF::Group|groups]], and [[../News::NAAF::Connection|server connections]]), while the implementation takes care of actually reading the stream (in possibly arbitrary order), uncompressing it as necessary, decoding the data and wrapping it into suitable Perl objects. This implementation will read only the ''parts'' of the NAAF stream relevant to the queries performed, provided that all the conditions below are met. # The filehandle associated with the NAAF stream is seekable. # The stream is ''properly terminated'' with an ''uncompressed'' delimiter record (the ''tail''), aligned to the ''tail alignment'' boundary (as specified in the NAAF stream header record.) # The tail has the ''last part length'' (or ''last part compressed length,'' if the stream is compressed) field properly set. # The last record of the last part (as pointed to by the tail) is the NAAF stream trailer, with its ''offsets'' field having all the subfields relevant to the queries to be performed properly set. (Please note that the ''parts'' subfield is currently used by ''all'' the implemented queries, along with the ''compressed parts'' subfield should the input stream be ''compressed''.) Otherwise, this implementation will fall back to reading the stream in order until the requested object is found, possibly uncompressing the stream, while also caching the data being read. Unless otherwise noted, the methods described below are “safe” in the sense that they always return the requested object, or raise an exception if the request cannot be fulfilled for some reason. == Interface ==
my $ro = News::NAAF::ReadOnly->new ($input);
my $ro = News::NAAF::ReadOnly->new ($input, \%options);

Return a new News::NAAF::ReadOnly object associated with the input filehandle given.

$ro->close ();

Close the News::NAAF::ReadOnly object, invalidating it for any future use, and potentially allowing for the memory occupied by the associated data structures to be reclaimed.

'''Note''' that it’s an error to use any method other than close itself on a News::NAAF::ReadOnly object after it has been closed with close.

my $naaf_header = $ro->header ();

Return the NAAF stream header as a [[../News::NAAF::NAAFHeader|News::NAAF::NAAFHeader]] object.

my $naaf_trailer = $ro->trailer ();

Return the NAAF stream trailer as a [[../News::NAAF::NAAFTrailer|News::NAAF::NAAFTrailer]] object.

my $article = $ro->article ($index);

Return the netnews article associated with the given non-negative integer index as a [[../News::NAAF::Article|News::NAAF::Article]] object.

my $connection = $ro->connection ($index);

Return the netnews server connection record associated with the given non-negative integer index as a [[../News::NAAF::Connection|News::NAAF::Connection]] object.

my $group = $ro->group ($index);

Return the newsgroup record associated with the given non-negative integer index as a [[../News::NAAF::Group|News::NAAF::Group]] object.

== See also == [[../News::NAAF::NAAFHeader|News::NAAF::NAAFHeader]], [[../News::NAAF::NAAFTrailer|News::NAAF::NAAFTrailer]] [[../News::NAAF::Article|News::NAAF::Article]], [[../News::NAAF::Connection|News::NAAF::Connection]], [[../News::NAAF::Group|News::NAAF::Group]], [[../News::NAAF::Common|News::NAAF::Common]] [//metacpan.org/pod/Convert::ASN1 Convert::ASN1], [//metacpan.org/pod/UUID UUID] == Author == News::NAAF::ReadOnly is written by Ivan Shmakov. News::NAAF::ReadOnly is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the 3-clause BSD license, as included within the code. This documentation is a free collaborative project going on at Wikibooks, and is available under the [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License] (CC BY-SA) version 3.0.

{{B3D:N2P/NAV |next=Basic Animation/Introducing the Graph Editor |nextText=Introducing the Graph Editor |previous=The Ways of the Animator |previousText=The Ways of the Animator }}
{{B3D:N2P/ForVersion|2.70}}
Blender offers several different kinds of editing windows specifically to do with animation.
== Timeline == You have previously come across the Timeline [[File:Blender270TimelineIcon.png]] view as the simplest way to see the keyframes in an animation. This window also includes transport controls that you can use to start and stop the animation, jump to a particular frame with {{B3D:N2P/Do|LMB}}, and scrub by dragging across a time range with {{B3D:N2P/Do|LMB}}.
This window also lets you define ''markers'' which you can name to identify important points in the animation, for informational purposes. Also, using the “Bind Camera to Marker” function, you can dynamically switch the active camera at marked points in the animation, to cut between different viewpoints.
== Graph Editor == You previously saw how to define keyframes for animating a property, such as an object position or material setting. But what if you get a keyframe definition slightly wrong? Perhaps the timing is slightly off, or the movement is not quite right. You could delete the keyframe and try again. But, in many cases, it would be easier if you could get into the actual definition of the keyframe and tweak it around a bit, move its time position, adjust the animated property values, that kind of thing.
This is the purpose of the Graph Editor [[File:Blender270GraphEditorIcon.png]]. It gives you the most detailed, low-level view possible of your animation, by drawing an ''FCurve'' for each animated property of the selected object, representing how the property value varies over time. Each curve has control points located at each of its keyframes, and you can move these points around—horizontally to change the timing, or vertically to change the keyframe value—as well as add and remove points.
== Dope Sheet == The Dope Sheet [[File:Blender270DopeSheetIcon.png]] gives a high-level view of your animation, similar to the Timeline, but slightly more detailed. Here you see the separate keyframes for each animated object, and you can do some limited editing, like moving the keyframes around, and duplicating and deleting keyframes, but you can’t seem to add entirely new ones.
Actually, this window can show any of five different editor submodes: Dope Sheet, Action Editor, Shape Key Editor, Grease Pencil or Mask. The Action Editor is useful in conjunction with the NLA Editor (below).
* '''See also:''' [http://wiki.blender.org/index.php/Doc:2.6/Manual/Animation/Editors/DopeSheet Dopesheet] on the Blender Wiki.
== NLA Editor == The NLA (“Non-Linear Animation”) Editor [[File:Blender270NLAEditorIcon.png]] represents a different way of setting up an animation: instead of thinking of it as a single linear sequence of keyframes, you break it up into ''actions'', which are separate sequences that can be arranged in various ways. You can also duplicate an action any number of times, position the copies at different times in the overall animation, and even attach them to different objects. But they still share a single set of FCurve contents, which you can edit in the Graph Editor as you would a monolithic linear animation sequence, and your changes will take effect in all copies of the action.
To edit the contents of an action in the Graph Editor, you select the action and {{B3D:N2P/Do|TAB}} into “tweak mode” (analogous to Edit mode in the 3D view). {{B3D:N2P/Do|TAB}} again takes you out of Tweak mode.
{{B3D:N2P/Note|'''Actions do not appear in the Timeline or Dope Sheet.''' This means that, once you start to use actions, you no longer get a correct overview of your animation in these two windows. The Timeline is still useful for its transport controls, but otherwise you should stick to the NLA Editor for your overview.}}
However, the Action Editor submode of the Dope Sheet now becomes useful, for creating new actions. These start out initially empty of any keyframes or FCurves, but you can add these in Tweak mode.
* '''See Also:''' [http://wiki.blender.org/index.php/Doc:2.6/Manual/Animation/Editors/NLA NLA Editor] on the Blender Wiki.
== To Summarize... == The above description may seem rather confusing in places. Basically, there are two ways to organize your animation: * Linear, as a single sequence of FCurves and keyframes * Non-linear, as a sequence of actions, each consisting of a sequence of FCurves and keyframes. The nonlinear data can be further divided into multiple overlapping ''tracks'', which combine together at any moment in time to produce the complete animation.
Objects that can have animation data attached to them can have both kinds, linear and nonlinear. You can even attach both kinds at once, though then the linear animation data takes precedence. It is easy to change your mind and switch back and forth; typically, the development of a simple animation might start out linear, then change to nonlinear as it gets more complicated.
{{B3D:N2P/NAV |next=Basic Animation/Introducing the Graph Editor |nextText=Introducing the Graph Editor |previous=The Ways of the Animator |previousText=The Ways of the Animator }}

[[Category:Trainz alternative name redirect pages|{{{1|{{SUBPAGENAME}}}}}]][[Category:Trainz alternative name redirect pages|*{{PAGENAME}},{{BOOKNAME}}]] [[Category:Self-documenting templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Trainz redirect templates|alt{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:auto-categorizing templates|alt{{PAGENAME}}]]
;Usage This page auto-categorized Trainz Wikibooks redirect terms into the auto-[[:Category:Trainz redirect pages]]. * It's proper placement is on '''the same line''' as the #redirect [[Trainz/whatever page name]] as in the below example: #redirect [[Trainz/whatever page name]]{{R from Trainz alternative name}} * to check the proper inclusion, separate the '#' from the word redirect like: # redirect [[Trainz/target page name]] {{R from Trainz alternative name}}
 
* It will sometimes also display the message in Preview if not properly installed, such as putting the template on a second line in the redirect page, hence the message might sometimes be produced indicating an error. ==See also== {{Trainz-redirect templates}}
This page is a redirect from a Wikibooks [[Trainz]] page which either has been moved, or renamed, or a colloquial term or abbreviation with coverage on the targeted page receiving redirected links.
#redirect [[Trainz/containers]]{{R from Trainz alternative name}}

{{Trainz-Admin}} {{Trainz-cat|text='''These pages are redirected pages created to alias other titles in the  [[Trainz]] Wikibook ''' :Many Trainz terms (especially various {{wp|keyword}}s or [[Trainz]]'s {{TR|S|p=Tags}}) will have to be searchable easily in the Wikibook, whilst the 'Topical Educational coverage' of the tag is in a sub-subpage's section title of the {{TR}} pages, or a level down from those. * To make those situations easily searchable and linkable, many such tag names will redirect in the form 'Trainz\tagname' subpages - with redirects to the proper page and section or {{tl|anchor}}. They then can be found in the search popups with the form: [Trainz/eng...] or the like, allowing Wikibooks scripts to suggest completions.
'''To place a page in this category there are three alternatives:''' # ''Explicit Longform:'' attach [[ category: Trainz alternative name redirect pages | {{CHAPTERNAME}} ]] directly and ''immediately after'' the '''#REDIRECT [[:Category:Trainz alternative name redirect pages|NewPageName]]''' entry, '''and ''on the same line'''' like this example:
#REDIRECT [[Trainz/NewPageName]][[ category: Trainz alternative name redirect pages | {{CHAPTERNAME}} ]]. # Use the more convenient: [[:Template:R from Trainz alternative name]] or it's shorter alias forms (to or from, doesn't matter) as shown next below. # Use [[:Template:R to TRS-alt]] (or the above) to auto-attach the category using just {{tl|R from Trainz alternative name}} or the shorter {{Tlx|R from TRS-alt|{{CHAPTERNAME}}}} ''immediately after'' the '''#REDIRECT [[:Category:Trainz alternative name redirect pages|NewPageName]]''' entry, '''and ''on the same line'''' like this example:
#REDIRECT [[Trainz/NewPageName]]{{R from TRS-alt}}. }} [[category:Trainz redirect pages]]

revision.comment: Regarding changing US English to International English
revision.text: Please don't change vocabulary from American English to International English or vice-versa as you did on [[Structural Biochemistry/Proteins/Fibrous Proteins]]. I'll admit that, for me, the spellings ''favour'' and ''fibre'' are more correct but people can use whatever form of English they wish on Wikibooks.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 14:01, 19 April 2014 (UTC)

==Welcome!== [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome to Wikibooks]]! You do not need to [[WB:LOGIN|log in]] to read or edit books at Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: * A username of your choice for directly attributing [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|your contributions]]. * A personal user page, a [[WB:TALK|talk page]], and a [[Help:Tracking changes#Watching pages|watchlist]] to monitor pages that interest you. * The ability to [[WB:MOVE|rename]] pages and to [[WB:PREFS|customize]] some aspects of the Wikibooks interface. * People will recognize you as a member of the Wikibooks community, and you will be eligible to [[WB:REVIEW|review]] pages. * Your IP address will be hidden from most users, which may give you a greater sense of security and privacy.
We hope that you choose to join our community as a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]]. Be sure to sign your talk page comments with four tildes (<nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>).
--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 12:49, 20 April 2014 (UTC)

[[File:Stop x nuvola with clock.svg|40px|left|link=]] '''[[Wikibooks:Blocking policy|You cannot edit]] for 1 month due to disruptive editing'''. You are welcome to contribute constructively when editing privileges are restored. You may appeal this action with a reasonable argument by adding the text {{tlx|unblock|Your reason here}} below.
--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 14:07, 20 April 2014 (UTC)

== Integration (alpha = 0.80, CR = 0.80) == === Description ===
Three relational competencies were identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Communication|communication]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Cooperation|cooperation]] and integration.
=== Definition ===
Integration refers to the process of combining efforts to integrate supplier and customer information and inputs into internal planning (Swink et al., 2007).
=== Items ===
To what extent do the statements apply to the relationship of your company with your suppliers and customers? (1 – strongly disagree; 7 – strongly agree):
*We have full access to joint planning systems. (0.80) *We synchronize our production plans. (0.67) *We carry out joint electronic data interchange. (0.62) *We have knowledge of inventory mix/levels. (0.77)
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1108/IJPDLM-08-2012-0243 Wieland/Wallenburg (2013): The Influence of Relational Competencies on Supply Chain Resilience: A Relational View. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, Vol. 42, No. 4, pp. 300-320.] Adapted from Frohlich/Westbrook (2001).
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Communication|Communication]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Cooperation|Cooperation]]
== Integration (alpha = 0.90) == === Description ===
Based on learning theory and multilevel thinking, measures were developed and validated for four types of team learning processes, as “team learning originates in individual [[Handbook of Management Scales/Intuition|intuition]], is amplified through [[Handbook of Management Scales/Interpretation|interpretation]] and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Integration|integration]], and manifests itself at the team level via the [[Handbook of Management Scales/Codification|codification]] of collective cognition and action”.
=== Definition ===
Integration is defined as “the process of developing shared understanding among individuals and of taking coordinated action through mutual adjustment” (Crossan et al., 1999, p. 525).
=== Items ===
*In our team, we managed to agree upon the actions and activities that we should perform. (0.86) *In our team, we shared information, ideas and results while performing project tasks. (0.96) *During the project, our team developed and experimented with a number of different implementation scenarios, project deliverables, prototypes or production designs. (0.96)
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0149206311419366 Kostopoulos et al. (2013): Structure and Function of Team Learning Emergence: A Multilevel Empirical Validation. Journal of Management, Vol. 39, No. 6, pp. 1430–1461]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with "== Agility (alpha = 0.85, CR = 0.84) == === Description === Two dimensions of resilience were identified: agility and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Robustness|robustness]]...."
revision.text:
== Agility (alpha = 0.85, CR = 0.84) == === Description ===
Two dimensions of resilience were identified: agility and [[Handbook of Management Scales/Robustness|robustness]].
=== Definition ===
Agility is defined as the ability of a supply chain to rapidly respond to change by adapting its initial stable configuration (Wieland/Wallenburg, 2012).
=== Items ===
Please indicate the speed of reaction with which your company can engage in the following activities should changes occur (1 – slow; 7 – fast):
*Adapt manufacturing leadtimes. (0.63) *Adapt level of customer service. (0.82) *Adapt delivery reliability. (0.85) *Adapt responsiveness to changing market needs. (0.76)
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1108/IJPDLM-08-2012-0243 Wieland/Wallenburg (2013): The Influence of Relational Competencies on Supply Chain Resilience: A Relational View. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, Vol. 42, No. 4, pp. 300-320.] Adapted from Swafford et al. (2006).
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Robustness|Robustness]]
{{BookCat}}

== Robustness (alpha = 0.87, CR = 0.87) == === Description ===
Two dimensions of resilience were identified: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Agility|agility]] and robustness.
=== Definition ===
Robustness is defined as the ability of a supply chain to resist change without adapting its initial stable configuration (Wieland/Wallenburg, 2012).
=== Items ===
To what extent do the statements apply to your supply chain? (1 – strongly disagree; 7 – strongly agree):
*For a long time, our supply chain retains the same stable situation as it had before changes occur. (0.71) *When changes occur, our supply chain grants us much time to consider a reasonable reaction. (0.73) *Without adaptations being necessary, our supply chain performs well over a wide variety of possible scenarios. (0.92) *For a long time, our supply chain is able to carry out its functions despite some damage done to it. (0.80)
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1108/IJPDLM-08-2012-0243 Wieland/Wallenburg (2013): The Influence of Relational Competencies on Supply Chain Resilience: A Relational View. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, Vol. 42, No. 4, pp. 300-320.]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Agility|Agility]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* A brief outline of Trainz history */ copy edit, settle on links destination
revision.text:
{{FUN-beg|alttitle1=Introductory Trainz: A brief outline of Trainz history}}   =A brief outline of Trainz history= [[File:TRS2004 historic advances, a Scenario--Hightand Valley Coal begins.JPG|thumb|TRS2004 made historic advances with interactive industries and an generalized extension of the Scenario system of single use TrainzScripts into today's powerful [[Trainz/sessions|sessions]]. * This TRS2004 Graphics panorama image on a laptop shows the first less developed yard at Greenwood station in a famous scenario shortly after it begins (called '''Highland Valley Coal''' by Chuck Cee Bee Barkman).
The map was slightly modified in TRS2004 as Highland Valley Industries (HVI) and used for an introduction to '''Interactive Industries Tutorial'''—a major advance in TRS2004's technologies—and republished in each release up through the release of {{TL|TS2009}}. That HVI map, adapted from this one, has a slightly expanded yard noticeably different in the left side of this view.]] Trainz was developed over 3–4 years beginning about 1996 in consultation and in collaboration with various model railroading clubs by Australian game developer {{wp|N3V Games|Auran Pty. Ltd}}, which had by then established itself as one of the premier gaming companies in Australia under the stewardship of chief programmer Greg Lane, Paul Olsen in development and Graham Edelsten. It's early releases were a pale shadow of what was to come but when released in 2001 the input of interested model railroaders quickly lead to a succession of improvements and extended capabilities. This became a pattern, accumulate major changes whilst setting up the evolution and making incremental changes and bug fixes through {{wp|service pack}} releases, each making a stable code software step. Trainz service packs unlike many commercial packages are free, and so the improvements continued steadily through releases in 2005 and Trainz 2006, which leveraged the stable and hard won game engine and features such as interactive industries being released with a powerful database manager, upload manager and download manager known as {{TL|Content Manager Plus}}, the father of today's CM utility which is little changed but for refinements. In 2005–2007 Auran over extended developing a different computer game (Fury) and Trainz and Auran both survived bankruptcy proceedings but the game now was managed under {{wp|N3V Games}} which renewed Trainz development leading to the "World Builder Edition, {{TL|TS2009}} and has continued to grow and evolve beating back several competitors over the ensuing decade years. Auran Development Pty Ltd became Auran Holdings Pty Ltd after the bankruptcy reorganization and still retains the rights to the program. The original chief engineer, and indeed most of the professional staff were lost during the dark months, and even the busy web site went dark for five weeks. N3V quickly hired back staff members willing to return, notably chief programmer Chris Bergmann who had joined the company in 2000. Bergmann can be frequently found inteacting on the Auran web board as ''''''Windwalkr''''''. (e.g. Google "{{Col|Site:forums.auran.com Windwalkr|blue")   ==Localisation== Multilingual language support has been built into Trainz since Trainz 1.3, increased in the best selling {{TL|TRS2004}} and expanded in the hugely popular {{TL|TRS2006}} (TR06) release in [[w:2005|2005]]. Next followed a handful of regionally focused releases including three in English based on the TR06 technologies which focused enclosed content featuring ''regional routes of interest'', albeit with some changes to unimportant graphics (skins) but some incremental alterations of data definitions portending events to come. These differed from TRS2004 and TRS2006 in the philosophy of bundled included content—instead of a potpourri of widely varying routes and their regional assets, the regionally focused routes were {{TG|S|scenery}} and {{TG|T|trackside asset}} biased by their thematic localizations, and tended to include less assets overall but perhaps more or interest to those also developing virtual railways in that same world region. Other TRS2006 spinoffs were European regional releases: ({{TL|TRS2007}} (France & French speaking lands) and {{TL|TRS2007|2008}} (German and Eastern European routes) which expanded the product's language offerings and soon added a rich supply of Europe and Eastern European routes. This same time span saw three English releases known as Trainz Classics ({{TL|TC1&2}} and {{TL|TC3}})—offerings partnered with third party content creators which delivered "professional quality" routes with a bounty of specialty assets and also offered slightly new technologies (V2.7 & V2.8, game engine advancements are usually first included in an English release), when N3v Games assumed control of publication and development. Year 2008 saw and end to 'game stagnation' with the release of {{TL|TS2009|TS2009: World Builders Edition}} sporting improvements mainly in Surveyor, 2009 the evolved dual-mode {{TL|TS2010|TS2010: Engineer's Edition}}, {{TL|TS2012|TS2012: 10th Anniversary Edition}} (aka '''TS12 or Trainz Simulator 2012''') which is the latest Microsoft Windows installment in the franchise and was released in April of 2011 and it's SP1 upgrades in late 2011. In 2012–2013 N3V games released Trainz MAC under the iOS operating system as well as tablet computer versions. Two targeted releases are in development for 2014, the later a full 64bit version with highly upgraded graphics known now as '''TANE or T:ANE, ''Trainz: A New Era''''' with funding in part supported by a modest amount raised by KickStarter pledges. {{FUN-bot}}

revision.comment: /* Iteration or any traversal of a collection is not part of the Visitor Pattern */ new section
revision.text:
== Iteration or any traversal of a collection is ''not'' part of the Visitor Pattern == This is a common misunderstanding of the Visitor Pattern. This pattern is only concerned with double-dispatch in computer languages which only provide a single-dispatch mechanism. It is possible to use this pattern to make single requests to elements of a collection, similar to direct or random file access. It is also possible to use the visitor pattern to drive the traversal of elements in a collection to obtain different ordering, filtering, maintaining state etc.
This pattern ''is especially useful'' when combined with the [[w:Composite pattern]] to define a hierarchical structure containing many instances of different elements from an object hierarchy, and to process those elements by traversing either a sub-branch or the complete tree structure. note: two types of hierarchies * a structure, a collection of instances of objects * object hierarchy, the definitions of unique, related classes with a common parent But, this is a particular specialization of the pattern, not simply the pattern itself.
I will let this information digest a while before embarking on changing the description.

revision.comment: Removed delete tag. Changed recipe to cooknav
revision.text:
{{cooknav}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian Cuisine]] {{recipesummary |Category= food recipes |Time=prep: 15 minutes
Bake: 15 Minutes
seasoning: 5minutes |Rating=3 |Image=[[File:Khaman.jpg|300px]] }} '''Khaman''' is baked fluffy snack made from gram flour. It is a traditional food from Gujarat state of India. [[File:Khaman Gujarati cuisine.jpg|thumb|Khaman]] ==Ingredients == * Bengal gram flour * [[Cookbook:Semolina|Semolina]] * Sugar powder * Lemon juice * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] * [[Cookbook:Sodium bicarbonate|Sodium bicarbonate]] * [[Cookbook:Turmeric|Tumeric powder]] * Cooking oil * Water ;Seasoning * Cooking oil * Asafetida * Mustard seeds * Grated coconut * Finely cut coriander leaves [[Category:Vegan recipes]]

=Uganda= * Uganda was a British colony until it gained independence in 1962. For several years after independence it’s postal affairs were managed communally with Kenya and Tanzania, and it used meter stamps inscribed with all three country names. Only a few postage meters were put into use with UGANDA alone as the country name. For stamps used before independence and for post-independence stamps inscribed KENYA, UGANDA and TANZANIA see EAST AFRICAN COMMUNITY. More stamp types than the two shown here are probably in use.
----
[[File: Uganda stamp type 1.jpg|left|370px]] '''1. Neopost “Frankmaster 305” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : Frank with simulated perforation outer border and inner box surrounding value figure. : Leaves at sides of value box. : “POST/ PAID” centered at bottom. : Spacing variable between TM and frank. : M# with “N” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00·00 [[File: Uganda stamp type 2.jpg|left|310px]]
'''2. National Cash Register''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$150] : '''Post Office stamp'''. : Frameless design printed on orange-yellow labels, never directly to covers. : Date at top above “UGANDA” underlined and curved with groups of three arcs at sides. : Value figures in center and impression counter number at right. : At bottom is ID letter “A” between arcs with “KAMPALA” at bottom. : Only Meter “A” known. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]–00.00 ----

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Doostdar!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''

Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
--[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 21:04, 21 April 2014 (UTC)
