revision.comment: Austncorp moved page [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans Recipe from South Texas]] to [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans of South Texas]]: Shortening the name.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Texas cuisine|Texas Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex Cuisine]] ==Ingredients== *1 lb (450g) dry [[Cookbook:Pinto Bean|pinto beans]] *8 cups water *1.5 Tbsp [[Cookbook:Paprika|paprika]] or 0.5 tsp ea. paprika & pepper *1.5 Tbsp granulated or brown sugar *1 Tbsp salt, or (2 tsp salt & a ham hock) *1.5 Tbsp [[Cookbook:Chili|chili]] powder *1/4 tsp [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder (or more) *1.5 Tbsp [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] - dehydrated or 1/2 small onion, finely diced *1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Bay leaf|bay leaves]] *5 cups water ==Procedure== #Wash beans carefully and soak overnight in 8 cups of water. #Drain and refill with 5 cups of water. #Add all the other ingredients. #Bring to a boil and simmer at least an hour, or until tender. #Remove bay leaves. #Do not drain prior to serving, the liquid is an important aspect of the dish. #Can be served using slotted spoon, to allow draining, or with a ladle into small side-dish bowls
Yield: 10 servings [[Category:Texas recipes]] [[Category:Tex-Mex recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]] [[Category:Side dish recipes]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]]
#REDIRECT [[Trainz/containers]]{{R from Trainz}}{{Bookcat}}

revision.comment: Austncorp moved page [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans Recipe from Central Texas]] to [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans of Central Texas]]
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Texas cuisine|Texas Cuisine]] ==Ingredients== *1 lb (450g) dry [[Cookbook:Pinto Bean|pinto beans]] *8 cups water *1 tsp ground black [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] *1 Tbsp [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] *1 ham bone or a rough equivalent of salt bacon *1 or 2 [[Cookbook:Bay leaf|bay leaves]] *5 cups water *perhaps a very small amount (3 oz) (~90g) of that morning's coffee (beverage, as opposed to grounds, etc.) (optional and never to be confirmed or denied as being an ingredient if asked) ==Procedure== #Wash beans carefully and soak overnight in 8 cups of water. #Drain and refill with 5 cups of water. #Add all the other ingredients. #Bring to a boil and simmer at least an hour, or until tender. #Remove bay leaves. #Do not drain prior to serving, the liquid is an important aspect of the dish. #Can be served using slotted spoon, to allow draining, or with a ladle into small side-dish bowls
Yield: 10 servings
The beans and the liquid can be ladled on to dry, stored cornbread (which, otherwise, can be exceptionally dry for eating purposes). The combination is very traditional. [[Category:Texas recipes]] [[Category:Bean recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]] [[Category:Side dish recipes]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]]

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, 電愛!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 01:15, 28 April 2014 (UTC)

If you are used to the syntax of MediaWiki templates, then you might be wondering about the syntax of the #invoke statement we saw in the previous chapter. The #invoke statement looked like this: 
{{#invoke:Hello|hello_world}}
As you can see, there are three parts: #invoke:, Hello, and hello_world. If we compare this to a template that does the same thing - outputs the text "Hello, world!" - we can see that there is only one part. 
{{Hello}}
The shared part is Hello, and in both cases this corresponds to the page name. For #invoke, it corresponds to the page [[Module:Hello]], and for the template it corresponds to the page [[Template:Hello]]. This leaves us with two extra parts to the #invoke statement: the #invoke: code itself, and hello_world. The #invoke: code is quite straightforward; all it is there to do is to tell the MediaWiki software that it is dealing with a Lua module, and not with a template or any other kind of special text.Text that has a special function in MediaWiki is known as a ''magic word'', and technically an #invoke statement is a particular kind of magic word called a ''parser function''. You can see more documentation about magic words and parser functions at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Magic_words. The hello_world code is where things get interesting. You may have noticed that hello_world appears in the middle of [[Module:Hello]]: p = {} function p.hello_world() return "Hello, world!" end return p It appears in a block of that starts with the keyword "function" and ends with the keyword "end". This is a ''function''. Functions in Lua are a lot like MediaWiki templates. You give templates input, the template processes the input, and it gives you some output. Functions are just the same; you give them input, the function processes the input, and it returns some output. In this case, we are not providing any input, as our function is very simple. (Later we will learn how to use the parentheses after hello_world to control input we are given.) The output in Lua functions is provided by the return keyword. In this case we are saying, "make a function with no inputs that outputs the text 'Hello, world!'" At the same time, we have given the function a name. while there are other ways to define a function in Lua, in this example the function name is everything after the code function and before the parentheses. In other words, the function name is p.hello_world. So why the p.? Why not just make the name hello_world? The answer is that the p. is how we tell Scribunto that we want our function to be available from #invoke. If we leave out the p., then we cannot run our function directly from any wiki pages. (There are ways that the function can be run ''indirectly'', but we will not cover those for now.) == Notes == {{BookCat}}

'''Amy Stroupe and BB&T''' is a professional ethics case that concerns [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowing]]. Amy Stroupe was hired by [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] on August 1, 2005 as a [[w:certified fraud examiner|certified fraud examiner]] (CFE) in Charlotte, N.C., and her courage as a [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblower]] and dedication to encourage transparency within [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] are tribute to her professionalism. In February, 2007, concerns were raised about a series of suspicious loans made by a [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] financial center manager in a real estate development, and Stroupe was notified by a retail service officer. In her investigative report, she indicated that a [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] employee had helped Village of Penland's developer design a $100 million [[w:Ponzi scheme|Ponzi scheme]]. <ref name=HuffingtonPost>Baker, M. (2010). Amy Stroupe: BB&T whistleblower vindicated by court ruling, to be rehired. Huffington Post. Retrieved from http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/02/amy-stroupe-bbt-whistlebl_n_523563.html</ref> [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] fired Stroupe soon after a meeting with the [[w:FBI|FBI]], claiming that she had violated company policies during her investigation, though she countered in court that she was fired as punishment for pushing too hard on the investigation.<ref name=InvestigativeFund>Hudson, M. (2010). When whistle-blowers fight back. The Investigative Fund. Retrieved from http://www.theinvestigativefund.org/investigations/economiccrisis/1314/when_whistle-blowers_fight_back </ref> She sued [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] under [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblower]] provisions, Section 806, and the federal judge in the case ruled that [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] must reinstate Stroupe with back pay. <ref name="FraudMag" />
==Professional Career==
===Early Career=== Prior to her career at [[w:BB&T|BB&T]], Amy Stroupe worked for the Cleveland County, N.C., Sheriff's Office as a detective. <ref name=FraudMag>Carozza, D. (2010). Sentinel wins vindication: An interview with Amy Stroupe, CFE, 2010 ACFE sentinel award recipient. Fraud Magazine. Retrieved from http://www.fraud-magazine.com/article.aspx?id=4294968657</ref>
===Whistleblowing and BB&T=== Stroupe began working for [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] at their Shelby branch on August 1, 2005, and while employed she excelled at her job as a corporate investigator. In her 90 day review report, her supervisor wrote, “Amy is an asset to the [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] Corporate Investigations team. Amy has established herself as a consistent contributor to the investigative team.”<ref name=Amyvs> Stroupe v. [[w:BB&T|BB&T]]. No. 07CUS2801. Cleveland County Superior Court. 6 December 2007. Retrieved from http://www.scribd.com/doc/3344601/Amy-Stroupe-v-BBT</ref> During her two years with [[w:BB&T|BB&T]], she had five positive performance reviews.<ref name="FraudMag" />
In February 2007, Stroupe was alerted about suspicious loans with Peerless Development Group. A branch manager named Bryan Drum had approved $20 million in loans for a development called the Villages of Penland.<ref name="Amyvs" /> Several suspicious patterns were apparent: all loan applicants were from out of state, the lots were appraised at a higher value than they were worth, all loans had the same appraiser and closing attorney, and Peerless used funds from their account to pay for some customer’s loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> Additionally, Drum was the only employee who worked with the Peerless loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> She first notified her supervisor, Brian Prater, and the Direct Retail division of her findings, but when no action was taken, she notified the Regional Portfolio administrator. Later, Stroupe informed the [[w:Fbi|FBI]]; Charlie Mattox, Drum’s supervisor; and several other [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] employees including the Regional President. In one meeting, an employee noted that the case “looks like securities fraud."<ref name="Amyvs" /> Upon further investigation, Stroupe found that Drum had been given a $10,000 bonus for the amount of loans he approved, and Drum had developed an incentive program between Peerless and its customers in which Peerless could pay its customer’s loans.<ref name="Amyvs" /> She also visited the Villages of Penland and found little development had been done on any of the lots. Despite her findings, Mattox did not immediately terminate Drum; instead he approved three additional Peerless loans that were already in the process of being approved. He contacted Stroupe advising her to work on other investigations and claimed that many parts of her report about Drum were false.<ref name="Amyvs" /> In April 2007, Drum was fired, and in retaliation, Mattox moved Stroupe from the Shelby branch to the Charlotte headquarters.<ref name="Amyvs" />
On May 22, 2007, a [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] attorney prevented Stroupe’s report to the [[w:Fbi|FBI]] from being sent since it contained incriminating information.<ref name="Amyvs" /> [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] would not only be liable for the $20 million they loaned but also for $120 million loaned to Peerless through other banks. The following day, the attorney stopped Stroupe from attending a meeting with [[w:Fbi|FBI]] officials stating that she would answer any question they asked her.<ref name="InvestigativeFund" /> Afterwards it was apparent that [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] denied any involvement in the scandal and failed to mention Bryan Drum. Despite resistance from upper management, Stroupe continued to investigate the scandal, and in retaliation, [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] fired her on June 20, 2007 stating that she had wrongfully discussed the details of her investigation with unauthorized personnel.<ref name="FraudMag" /> At this time, her boss said, “Amy, it’s become obvious that you cannot conform to a corporate setting; therefore, we are terminating your employment." <ref name="FraudMag" />
===Aftermath=== After termination, Stroupe filed a complaint with [[w:Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]], but after months of investigation, they found that her claims lacked any merit.<ref name=Ruling>Galindo, D. (2012). Ruling in [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] case likely to take months Fraud Magazine. Retrieved from http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/ruling-in-bb-t-case-likely-to-take-months/article_80092f03-8fc1-56cb-b8e9-5dd42e52fbe6.html?mode=jqm</ref> She appealed under the [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] and won three years later, winning her job back with back pay plus interest.<ref name="InvestigativeFund"/> Her case is notable because it is one of the 3.6% that have won under the [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|SOX]] act.<ref name="InvestigativeFund"/>
==Whistleblowing== [[w:Whistleblower|Whistleblowing]] refers to making a disclosure that evidences illegal or improper government or corporate activities. <ref name=Fas>Whitaker, L. P. (2007). The whistleblower protection act: An overview. CRS Report for Congress. Retrieved from http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RL33918.pdf</ref> By disclosing information about corruption, fraud, mismanagement and other wrongdoing, [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] have helped save billions of dollars in public funds while preventing emerging scandals and disasters from worsening. <ref name=TransInt>Transparency International. (2013). International principles for whistleblower legislation: Best practices for laws to protect whistleblowers and support whistleblowing in the public interest. Retrieved from http://www.transparency.org/whatwedo/pub/international_principles_for_whistleblower_legislation </ref> ===Perception and Protection=== Perceptions of [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] tend to vary. While sources such as [[w:Time (magazine)|Time]] have often praised whistleblowers for their actions, others have accused them of being traitors. <ref name=Time>Person of the year: A photo history. (2002). Retrieved from http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2019712_2019710_2019677,00.html </ref><ref name=Traitor>Harwood, W. H. (2013). Whistleblower or traitor, Snowden must shut up. Huffington Post. Retrieved from http://www.huffingtonpost.com/william-h-harwood/whistleblower-or-traitor-_b_4143834.html </ref> Since [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers']] broad spectrum of public perception deepens the riskiness of their actions, civil society has played a large role in protecting whistleblowers from public retaliation, legal liability, and cultural barriers. <ref name=SSRN>Banisar, D. (2011). Whistleblowing: International standards and developments. Social Science Research Network. Retrieved from http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1753180 </ref> In recent decades, many non-governmental organizations such as [[w:Transparency International|Transparency International]], [[w:Government Accountability Project| Government Accountability Project]], Public Concern at Work, and the Open Democracy Advice Centre have arisen to inspire legislative protection for whistleblowers apropos their risks and publicize corruption across international workplaces. Efforts to improve and expand whistleblowing legislation have helped protect [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblowers]] from their risks, while also easing detection of corruption and enhancing accountability in corporate and political environments. <ref name=TransInt /> Though the threshold for whistleblower protection is difficult to define, current principles regarding whistleblowing legislation suggest protection should be granted for disclosures made with a reasonable belief of wrongdoing at the time of disclosure. <ref name=TransInt /> Though these principles don’t always translate into legislation, they help direct the formulation of new and improvement of current legislation.
===United States Legislation=== Whistleblowing's history is deep. In 1863, the [[w:False Claims Act|United States False Claims Act]] allowed citizens to sue on the government's behalf in cases of fraud and collect rewards for doing so. <ref name=SSRN /> This action is often known as [[w:Qui tam|qui tam]], a writ originating in Roman times as a law enforcement mechanism. <ref name=GeorgiaLaw> Beck, J. R. (2000). The False Claims Act and the English eradication of qui tam legislation. University of Georgia School of Law. Retrieved from http://digitalcommons.law.uga.edu/fac_artchop/279/ </ref> Whistleblowing was modernly campaigned by [[w:Ralph Nader|Ralph Nader]] in the 1960s when he launched a movement to encourage scientists, engineers, and other professionals to "blow the whistle" on unethical principles by their employers. <ref name=Science>Boffey, P. (1971). Nader and the scientists: A call for responsibility. Science, 171(3917), 549-551. Retrieved from http://www.sciencemag.org/content/171/3971/549.extract </ref> Following his drive and tragedies like the [[w:Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Challenger disaster of 1986]], many whistleblowing laws were passed such as the [[w:Whistleblower Protection Act| Whistleblower Protection Act of 1989]], which protects government employees from management retaliation and is considered to be among the most important pieces of whistleblower legislation. <ref name=SSRN /> Scandals have also encouraged more recent legislation. In the 2002, the [[w:Enron scandal|Enron]] and [[w:Worldcon|Worldcon]] scandals inspired the adoption of the [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], which requires international corporations that are either owned in part by United States companies or traded on United States stock exchanges to adopt whistleblowing procedures. <ref name=SSRN /> Supporting such federal legislation, the [[w:National Conference of State Legislatures|National Conference of State Legislatures]] has adopted unique laws protecting whistleblowers for different states.<ref name=NCSL>State whistleblower laws. (2010). National Conference of State Legislatures. Retrieved from http://www.ncsl.org/research/labor-and-employment/state-whistleblower-laws.aspx </ref>
==BB&T==
===Organizational Culture=== [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] was part of the financial climate of the mid-to-late 2000s. The [[w:United States housing bubble|estate boom]] was in full swing, and there was pressure to approve loans without much investigation. According to attorneys of victims of the Village of Penland scheme, it is now hard to support the claim that banks involved conducted any [[w:Due diligence|due diligence]] investigations that the general public would expect. <ref name=Lexis>Steeves, C. (2008). Feds: Western N.C. Mountain developers pleading guilty in $100M fraud. The Mecklenburg Times. Retrieved from http://www.lexisnexis.com/lnacui2api/results/docview/docview.do?docLinkInd=true&risb=21_T19777490799&format=GNBFI&sort=RELEVANCE&startDocNo=1&resultsUrlKey=29_T19777490760&cisb=22_T19777490759&treeMax=true&treeWidth=0&csi=362848&docNo=9 </ref> [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] has maintained that it was a victim of the scheme, citing their loss of $20 million. <ref name=HPE>Johnson, P. (2010). BB&T woes raise questions about leader’s regional role. High Point Enterprise.</ref> These losses occurred after the scheme was revealed, however, and [[w:BB&T|BB&T’s]] prior actions leave doubt regarding it’s innocence.
Though Stroupe first alerted her bosses in March, 2007, they dismissed her concerns. <ref name=Factivia>Weiss, M. (2009). Judge refuses to close BB&T whistleblower case. Factivia. Retrieved from https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APRS000020090601e5610020d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from= </ref> She sought out other superiors in the company and even went to the Associated Press, but met with similar results. <ref name=Factivia /> Even if [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] was not complicit with the scheme, its culture hindered it’s undoing and reaped the rewards in the meantime. Developer Tony Porter had promised investors returns as high as 10%, but instead of questioning that number, [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] turned a blind eye. <ref name=WSJ> Carrns, A. (2007). ‘I feel like an idiot’ land project gone wrong shows how even well-off lured by Go-Go Climate. The Wall Street Journal. Retrieved from http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB118472035759069734 </ref> If [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] was indeed a victim, why were they not concerned by Stroupe’s reports of foul play? According to federal judge Stanley Tureck, [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] actually aided the fraud. <ref name=FraudMag />
===Repercussions=== [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] faced very few consequences after Stroupe revealed the Penland Village [[w:Ponzi scheme|ponzi scheme]]. The court ruling ordered [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] to pay Stroupe three years salary and rehire her, but they never actually brought Stroupe back to the company.<ref name=HPE /> They merely placed her on the payroll without any responsibilities, claiming they had laid off all investigative staff in the region and her position therefore no longer existed. <ref name=WSJ /> [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] stated that it intended to appeal the ruling, but after being granted several extensions for their briefing, allowed their appeal to be dismissed. <ref name=USDL>Stroupe v. Branch Banking & Trust Co. (2010). United States Department of Labor. Retrieved from http://www.oalj.dol.gov/PUBLIC/ARB/DECISIONS/ARB_Decisions/SOX/10_086.SOXP.HTM </ref> Stroupe returned to her previous job in law enforcement at the Cleveland County Sheriff’s Office. <ref name=FraudMag />
Several people faced trial and were sentenced because of the Penland Village scheme, including the developers Tony Porter, Frank Amelung, and John Foster. <ref name=Lexis /> No individual from [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] was accused of any wrongdoing.
Most of the attention on [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] in the aftermath of the ruling was directed towards its other interests and its [[w:Chief executive officer|CEO]], [[w:Kelly King|Kelly King]]. The director of N.C. Policy Watch, Rob Schofield expressed concern that the ruling would damage [[w:BB&T|BB&T’s]] other business components. <ref name=HPE />
Several banks sued individual investors to recover their loans, and some have settled. Many of those affected, however, are in financial ruin because of the scheme. <ref name=Factivia /> Investors were left with monthly payments as high as $9,000 on land that is worth a small fraction of what they paid for. <ref name=WSJ />
==Conclusions== ===Whistleblower Protection=== There are 18 different acts which protect [[w:whistleblower|whistleblowers]] within the Unites States. <ref name=WhistleblowerActs>Whistleblowerlaws. (2014). Whistleblower Protections. Whistleblowerlaws. Retrieved from http://www.whistleblowerlaws.com/whistleblower-protections-act/</ref> The [[w:Sarbanes-Oxley Act|Sarbanes Oxley Act (SOX)]] is the primary protection act which defends individuals who report financial fraud with “strong and unprecedented anti-retatliation protection for corporate employees.” This act has been unsuccessful in protecting [[w:whistleblower|whistleblowers]], however, yielding a win rate of 3.6% in initial trials and 6.5% in appeals. <ref name=WilliamAndMaryLawReview>Moberly, R. (2007). Unfulfilled Expectations: An Empirical Analysis of Why Sarbanes-Oxley Whisleblowers Rarely Win. William and Mary Law Review 49(1). Retrieved from http://scholarship.law.wm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1115&context=wmlr</ref> The case of Amy Stroupe and [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] shows that federal reporting of misconduct can be successful under the [[w:Sarbanes Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], but this result is rare. Other whistleblowing cases such as Nicholas P. Tides & Matthew C. Neumann v. The Boeing Company resulted in failure using SOX. The motion failed because the court ruled that “leaks to the media are not protected” under [[w:Sarbanes Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]]. <ref name=BoeingCase>Cougheneur, J. (2010). Nicholas P. Tides & Matthew C. Neumann v. The Boeing Company. United States Court Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Retrieved from http://www.rcfp.org/newsitems/docs/20110504_150355_op.pdf</ref>
The purpose for excluding media leaks from protection is to protect confidentiality of corporate financial records. <ref name=MediaExclusionPurpose>Egelko, B. (2011). Boeing ex-employees lose whistle-blower case. SFGate. Retrieved from http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Boeing-ex-employees-lose-whistle-blower-case-2324900.php</ref> Multiple issues arise, though, from prohibiting reports to the media. First, reporting misconduct internally or to federal authorities is less effective because of pressure from agencies. The U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board found that “agencies have the power to influence employees’ decisions about reporting wrongdoing” and around one-third of people who realized misconduct received pressure to not report. <ref name=MeritReviewBoard>U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board. (2011). Blowing the Whistle: Barriers to Federal Employees Making Disclosures. U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board. Retrieved from http://www.mspb.gov/netsearch/viewdocs.aspx?docnumber=662503&version=664475</ref> Second, reporting of fraud through federal agencies is inherently a much slower and labor intensive process than simply providing information to media outlets. Lastly, a conflict of interest is present for federal agencies that are obligated to protect whistleblowers who harm corporations, even though these agencies receive money from corporations through lobbying. [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] and [[w:Boeing|Boeing]] each have given millions of dollars annually to the U.S. government through lobbying. <ref name=OpenSecrets1>Center for Responsive Politics. (2013). Annual Lobbying by Boeing Co. OpenSecrets.org. Retrieved from http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000000100</ref> <ref name=OpenSecrets2>Center for Responsive Politics. (2013). Annual Lobbying by BB&T Corp. OpenSecrets.org. Retrieved from http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000021868</ref> The pressures and problems with financial fraud reporting support the need for inclusion of media leaks in [[w:Whistleblower protection in the United States|whistleblower protection laws]], particularly under the [[w:Sarbanes Oxley Act|Sarbanes-Oxley Act]].
===Professionalism=== The case of Amy Stroupe and [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] provides multiple possible characteristics that define professional ethics. Stroupe willingly defied her superiors within her company by reporting internal financial fraud. She chose to risk her job to maintain her integrity through reporting the truth, even under pressure to keep quiet. After she realized this risk through her termination, she continued the fight against [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] in court and won. Her courage to defy, not only in her initial reporting but also in her legal pursuits, is potentially a strong characteristic of professionals in any field. Stroupe’s willingness to risk her job also shows courage, and is another potential characteristic of professionalism.
Her victory has set an example for others showing that those that defy their employers to maintain their integrity can still ultimately achieve success. Stroupe stated following her victory in court against [[w:BB&T|BB&T]] that she has “a lot more courage and confidence” and that “the experience has made [her] as determined as ever to report the truth.” <ref name=FraudMag /> Stroupe’s experience supports the conclusion that professional actions inspire further professional actions, especially if these actions reward the actor. This lesson, if true, motivates the rewarding of professional actions in general. In the case of Amy Stroupe, this lesson validates the argument that [[w:Whistleblower|whistleblower]] protections should be improved so that other professionals can be protected just as Stroupe was.
==References== <references />
{{BookCat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Galzigler!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:25, 28 April 2014 (UTC)

Thanks. }} You will be blocked from editing if you carry out further vandalism.

page.title: Source SDK: Mastering the Source/What is Hammer?

revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=What is Hammer?|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]}} [[File:Hammer editor logo.jpg|right|200px]]
What is Hammer? A very important question, and one that will be covered thoroughly throughout this page.
=The Hammer World Editor= [[File:Application browser-hammer editor.jpg|right|300px]] Hammer, or the Hammer World Editor is a free level editing and creation program supplied by the Source SDK. Hammer comes with a number of unique features other than standard level design programs, making it one of the most popular choices on the market. Hammer has been used to develop many games, both by major video game companies and independent developers, and always shows favorable results. The Hammer Editor is easy to learn with a few tutorials, but with the help of this book, you'll be able to master it and all it has to offer.
=How do I use it?= The Hammer Editor is known for it's easy to learn interface and variety of creation tools. You will literally find an endless array of tools and programs specifically designed to create the level of your choosing, if you can build it in your mind, you can build it in Hammer. Of course you have to learn it first, that's where this book comes in. With your devotion and cooperation with this book you be able to learn every flip, switch, and button in Hammer, and how to master every one.
=Improving your Skills= The goal of this book is to make sure you can understand and operate the Hammer Editor, if all goes correctly, you will notice your skills improve drastically as you move from chapter to chapter in Section 1. These pictures below will give you a clear indication of your soon to be progress through Hammer, and show you what you can expect to accomplish with the help of this book.
All right, now that we've covered just what the Hammer Editor is, it's time to learn how to use it.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=What is Hammer?|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]}}

page.title: Source SDK: Mastering the Source/File Menu

revision.comment: Created page with "{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|Next..."
revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu|Edit Menu]]}}
The File drop down box is the first item located on the Control Bar. It allows you to save, run, and compile your map, as well as perform a number of useful configuration programs.
==New(Control+N)== Creates a new blank map.
==Open...(Control+O)== Open a previously created or downloaded map. A set of recently opened maps will appear at the bottom of the File drop down box, for easy access to a map you've previously been working on.
==Close== Closes a currently opened map. Of course you can always skip this step and simply move onto opening another map, thereby closing the current map automatically.
==Save(Ctrl+S)== Saves the current version of an already created map.
==Save as== Saves a newly created map as a brand new file.
==Export==
==Export Again==
==Export to .DXF==
==Run Map(F9)== Compiles and launches your map, allowing you to personally play test it in game. You do not have to save the changes to your map in order for them to appear in game. On occasion, if you accidentally press F10 instead of F9, you're temporarily unable to launch your map by hotkey, so simply use the button located in the File drop down box.
==Convert WAD to VMT...==
==Reload Sounds==
==Exit== Closes out the Hammer Editor. Does not close out the Application Browser. Of course this can alternatively be done by clicking the red 'X' icon in the top right corner.
=Notes= * If you are currently editing a map when you select the new, open, close, save, save as, or exit button, a question box will appear asking if you'd like to save any currently unsaved changes to your map.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=File Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/The Control Bar|The Control Bar]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu|Edit Menu]]}}

page.title: Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Edit Menu

revision.text:
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=Edit Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/File Menu|File Menu]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Map Menu|Map Menu]]}}
The Edit Menu on the Control Bar houses a variety of useful tools that can assist you in creating your map.
==Undo(CTRL+Z)== This button undos any action or edit you've made to anything in your level. The undo button has a limit.
==Redo(CTRL+Y)== This button gives you the opportunity to redo an undo. The Redo button has a limit.
==Toggle Undo/Redo== This button toggles ON and OFF your ability to use the Redo and Undo tools.
==Find Entities(Ctrl+Shift+F)== This button opens a small search box that allows you to search any entity you have in your level, in case you have misplaced them. (add image of find entity search box)
==Replace...(Ctrl+Shift+R)== This button opens a small search box that allows you to take any entity in your map and replace it with another. (add image of replace search box)
==Cut(Ctrl+X)== Cuts a selected brush or entity out of the level and onto your clip board, for it to be pasted.
==Copy(Ctrl+C)== Copies a selected brush or entity out of the level and onto your clip board, for it to be pasted.
==Paste(Ctrl+V)== Pastes whatever item you have in your clipboard onto the map. Because the button pastes the item as soon as you click it, making it difficult to aim where you paste it when using the drop down box, so it's smarter to use the hotkey.
==Paste Special==
==Delete(Del)== Deletes any selected brush or entity within the map.
==Clear Selection== De-selects any brush or entity you have selected in the map.
==Select All== Simultaneously selects all brushes and entities in the entire map.
==Properties== Shows the current properties of a selected entity.
{{Simple Page Navigation|BookName=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source]]|CurrentPage=Edit Menu|PrevPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/File Menu|File Menu]]|NextPage=[[Source SDK: Mastering the Source/Map Menu|Map Menu]]}}

revision.comment: Corrected link to pinto bean recipe.
revision.text:
{{cuisine|Texas}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North America]] | [[Cookbook:United States|United States]] '''Texas cuisine''' is a cuisine, the fundamentals of which are deeply rooted in the history of [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] production in [[wikipedia:Texas|Texas]] and the difficult life of a particular group early Texas settlers, primarily those settlers who started immigrating into what was then the Mexican state of [[wikipedia:Coahuila y Tejas|Coahuila y Tejas]] from the U.S. in the early 1800’s. Several fundamental recipes of modern Texas cuisine are based on the cuisine developed by these particular early settlers (who were aided by substantial contributions from other cuisines of the time).
Texas cuisine also includes contributions from the cuisines of later immigrants to Texas which augmented the early Texas cuisine, and can also be considered to include a very wide variety of recipes and food items thought to have originated in Texas, or which are otherwise attributed to Texas, which are not based on, or related to, the early historic roots of Texas cuisine.
Perhaps some of the very most fundamental recipes of Texas Cuisine to learn and attempt to master are [[Cookbook:Southern Cornbread|cornbread]], [[Cookbook:Pinto Beans of Central Texas|pinto beans]], [[Cookbook:Original Texas-Style Chili|chili]], and, for a group, barbecued or smoked beef brisket.
Texas cuisine is distinguishable from [[Cookbook:Tex-Mex cuisine|Tex-Mex cuisine]] in that the foundations of Texas cuisine seem to relate more to the cuisine developed by the particular group of settlers mentioned above, although there are overlaps, similarities, and substantial borrowing between the two. ==Recipes== For a list of recipes see the [[:Category:Texas recipes|Texas recipes category]]. If you are reading this on the [[Cookbook:Texas cooking|Texas cooking]] page, all of the recipes in the Texas recipes category should already be listed to the right.

revision.comment: comment about examples within the command listing
revision.text: I had mixed feeling about the use of examples in the GHCi command list, i.e. the use of specific module names. I think by this point, the concept should be clear without the concrete examples. The challenge is how to express clearly when something is an example. I don't have strong feelings here though. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 04:17, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

revision.text:
{{archive nav}} In the first listing, 
where less = filter (< x) xs
and below - don't work in my GHCi. Have to write it like this: 
	where
	less = filter (< x) xs
etc. :Are you sure? I copied-and-pasted it into h.hs, and did a :load "/home/gwern/h.hs" within GHCi and sure enough: *Main> quickSort [1,5,8,15,1,3,4] [1,1,3,4,5,8,15] :----[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 20:08, 8 February 2007 (UTC) I was wrong: the trouble was caused by an editor with non-monospace font, so while it seemed that code is well indented, it was, in fact, not. Sorry. == almost completed? == calling Eric: now that this section has the currying section filled up, can you just give it a revision and remove that irriatating 50% completed symbol? — 58.106.132.214, 2008-02-26T10:14:26 I'll at least remove the stub tag. —[[User:Toby Bartels|Toby Bartels]] ([[User talk:Toby Bartels|talk]]) 21:56, 18 November 2008 (UTC) == 2014-04-29 refactoring == The case for quickSort [x] = [x] is strictly unnecessary. Do we want to omit it? Is it good form to include it in real programs? If so, I say we keep it and explain why it helps. I'm guessing it is more efficient. Despite Haskell's laziness, maybe this is faster than running through the full recursive pattern to verify that a single-element list stays the same. If so, we should explain. If not, maybe we should just remove this extraneous thing. Or maybe it should just be a comment but not be included in the actual example code. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 16:52, 29 April 2014 (UTC) :I think we should remove it. While it might help performance a little bit, the cute one-liner quicksort we use here is relatively inefficient anyway (three passes through filter per step, indiscriminate usage of (++)), so there is no need to bother with small optimisations like that one. As for the "this is more explicit" justification in the book, it is far off the mark - adding redundant patterns makes code harder to read. Even in things like Data.List, which was written to provide decent performance, you don't find [x] patterns (the only one in Data.List is a genuine base case in the mergesort implementation).--[[User:Duplode|Duplode]] ([[User talk:Duplode|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Duplode|contribs]]) 09:09, 30 April 2014 (UTC) :I removed those. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 18:36, 30 April 2014 (UTC) Something with the indentation is wrong in the code now, but I'm not sure what the issue is, why it is wrong. [[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 18:16, 29 April 2014 (UTC) :Do you have any specific code block in mind? After a quick glance I didn't see anything strange (other than the where clauses indented half a mile to the right for no good reason).--[[User:Duplode|Duplode]] ([[User talk:Duplode|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Duplode|contribs]]) 09:09, 30 April 2014 (UTC) : I adjusted the extreme indentation, but it was the second and third cases under the where were not lining up quite right in my rendering. To fix it, I moved all three cases to separate lines from the where.

{{archive nav}}
== List comprehensions == I'm reading the book from the beginning, and the List comprehensions part seems way too complicated: particularly because of "(we'll assume that a test for evenness exists called ifEven):" is a bad assumption ;-). If I can't try out the code, I can't experiment with it, and I can't understand it. --gerymate
:That any better now? --[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 18:40, 27 October 2006 (UTC)
::Better for me, but I think, list comprehensions are way too high level for this stage. At this point we haven't learnt control structures, neither | this | that statements, nor the term "otherwise". "mod" is also new here, but it's all right... I think, list comprehensions shouldn't be in the 'Haskell Basics' section. --gerymate
:::Oh. I didn't even realize that guards hadn't been covered yet. As for mod... it might be rewritable in terms of regular old division (since that's what mod really is). As for 'otherwise', isn't that pretty clear? --[[User talk:Gwern |Gwern]] [[Special:Contributions/Gwern | (contribs)]] 02:09, 28 October 2006 (UTC)
== Missing Material == Shouldn't the discussion of lists include a mention of the "head" and "tail" functions? I was completely lost trying to do what I thought was simple list processing (with my only exposure to Haskell so far being this tutorial), until another reference (http://www.cs.utah.edu/~hal/docs/daume02yaht.pdf) mentioned those two functions. I knew there had to be some car/cdr equivalent, and just as car/cdr are among the first Lisp functions you would learn, shouldn't head/tail be mentioned here?
== Pattern matching should have been explained a while ago ==
Please see the [[Haskell/Notes_for_contributors|notes for contributors]]. --[[User:Digichoron|Digichoron]] ([[User talk:Digichoron|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Digichoron|contribs]]) 17:27, 5 April 2011 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Imjagpul!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 09:53, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

{{tmbox|type=notice|text='''Please help ''improve'' Wikibooks'''. Please read [[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks?]] for a description of what we allow. You can ask questions or ask for help in the [[WB:HELP|Assistance Reading Room]]. Thanks. [[User:Glaisher|Glaisher]] ([[User talk:Glaisher|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Glaisher|contribs]]) 09:58, 30 April 2014 (UTC)}}

__TOC__
Since its first days SQL includes a basic form of '''pattern matching on strings'''. The feature is part of the WHERE clause and is triggered by the key word LIKE. It knows two meta-characters: '_' (underscore) and '%' (percent). SELECT * FROM WHERE LIKE ; -- The like_criterion can contain '_' and/or '%' Over time, additional functionality has been incorporated to the standard. This concerns regular expressions, which are similar to those defined by [[Regular_Expressions/POSIX_Basic_Regular_Expressions|POSIX]], and regular expressions as defined by the XQuery 1.0 / XPath 2.0 function [http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions/#string.match fn:matches()]. Finally the SQL application package [[w:SQL#Standardization|ISO/IEC 13249-2:2003 Part 2: Full-Text]] defines methods and functions for information retrieval on fulltext. == LIKE == The LIKE predicate compares a column of type CHAR or VARCHAR (string) with a pattern. This pattern is also a string, but it may contain two characters with a special meaning. The '_' (underscore) represents exactly one arbitrary character and '%' (percent) represents a string of zero, one or more characters. All other characters represent themselfes. The first example retrieves all rows from table ''person'' with a first name starting with the two characters 'Jo', eg: 'John', 'Johanna' or 'Jonny W.'. As the meta-character '%' represents also zero characters, rows with the first name 'Jo' are also retrieved. SELECT * FROM person WHERE firstname LIKE 'Jo%'; The next example retrieves all rows from table ''person'' with a last name similar to 'Meier', eg: 'Meyer' or 'Maier'. The two underscores represents exactly two (arbitrary) characters. Consider, that there may be unexpected results like 'Miler' (but not 'Miller'). SELECT * FROM person WHERE lastname LIKE 'M__er'; The definition of the two meta-characters '_' and '%' implies a problem: What if one wants to search for this characters itself? The solution is the same as in other programming languages: one defines an escape mechanism to mask the meta-characters and prefix the meta-character in the pattern by this escape character. In SQL the syntax is: ... WHERE LIKE ESCAPE ;
-- Retriev one of the meta-characters: 'Electric_Motor' but not 'Electric Motor' SELECT * FROM parts WHERE partname LIKE 'Electric\_Motor' ESCAPE '\';
-- Retrieve the escape character itself: 'Electric\Motor' but not 'Electric Motor' SELECT * FROM parts WHERE partname LIKE 'Electric\\Motor' ESCAPE '\'; The escape character can be any character, it is not limited to the back slash, eg.: ... ESCAPE '!' == POSIX Semantic == In an outdated version of the SQL standard there was the key word SIMILAR which introduced a pattern match in the sence of [[Regular_Expressions/POSIX_Basic_Regular_Expressions|POSIX]]. Nowadays it is deprecated. Some implementations offer pattern matching in this sense, but use arbitrary key words like REGEXP, REGEXP_MATCHES, REGEXP_LIKE or operators like '~' to activate the feature. == XQuery Semantic == The SQL standard defines the key word LIKE_REGEX to activate pattern matching as defined by the XQuery 1.0 / XPath 2.0 function [http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions/#string.match fn:matches()]. == Full-Text == The SQL standard is complemented by ''ISO/IEC 13249 SQL Multimedia and Application Packages''. Part 2 ''Full-Text'' defines routines and methods for information retrieval in text documents. It deals with objects like: word, phrase, sentence and paragraph. Therein are special constructs to seach for words or phrases, words within a definable distance, thesaurus features like broader terms of a word, soundex-similarity, ranking of results, and much more. The central methode of this features is CONTAINS. -- Retrieve rows with 'word_1' and 'word_2' (in this order) within a sequence of 10 words. SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE CONTAINS(' "word_1" NEAR "word_2" WITHIN 10 WORDS IN ORDER ') = 1; Such features are fare beyond pattern matching - but it is the natural next step. SQL implementations offer them mostly in combination with special text indexes.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Lemorrison!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:55, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==

[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)

* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted?
