Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:15, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

On March 23, 2005, an explosion occurred at the isomerization process unit of the BP’s Texas City Refinery located in Texas City, Texas. The explosion killed 15 workers and injured more than 170 others.<ref name="BP Report" />
==Background== The Texas City Oil Refinery was built in 1934 and purchased by BP in 1999. It had been previously owned and operated by Amoco since its creation. Under Amoco ownership the refinery had a history of postponing major upgrades due to a cost saving management style.<ref name="BP Troubled Past">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/the-spill/bp-troubled-past/ | title=BP's Troubled Past | publisher=PBS.org |date=May 2014}}</ref> As of 2005, the Texas City refinery was the second largest refinery in the state and third largest in the country, processing up to 437,000 barrels of crude oil per day. It is currently the fifth largest such refinery in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/neic/rankings/refineries.htm | title=U.S. Refineries* Operable Capacity | publisher=Department of Energy, Energy Information Administration |date=May 2014}}</ref> The Texas City Refinery is unique in that it can process over 50 different types of crude oil into a wide variety of products ranging from traditional gas and diesel to jet fuel.<ref>{{cite web| first1= Emily | last1 = Pickrell | display-authors= 1 | url=http://www.chron.com/business/article/BP-looks-to-positives-in-effort-to-sell-Texas-3785665.php | title=BP Looks to Positives in Effort to Sell Texas City Refinery | publisher=Houston Chronicle- Heart Publishing |date=May 2014}}</ref>
==Explosion== [[File:BP PLANT EXPLOSION-1 lowres2.jpg|thumb|Fire-extinguishing operations after the explosion]] On March 23, 2005, 15 people were killed and another 170 injured after an explosion occurred at the Texas City Refinery. The explosion was a direct result of a malfunction of hardware in the isomerization unit. At approximately 2:00 AM, engineers routinely turned on the hydrocarbon intake valve to release highly flammable liquid hydro-carbons into a raffinate splitter tower. During routine operations, this tower is supposed to fill to around 6 feet of fluid before a sensor will advise the engineers to cease hydro-carbon release. However, on this day, the safety alarm failed to go off and by the time engineers were able to identify that the tower was over-filling at around 3:30 AM, the level of hydro-carbons had reached 13 feet. This level was maintained during the night until normal day operations began again at around 9:30 AM. At this time, however, operators kept pumping fuel into the splitter tower but failed to open the outtake valve, and because the splitter tower warning system had already failed, flammable fluid built up in the tower to over 20 times the normal height, or approximately 138 feet while the sensors indicated the level was at a normal 10 feet.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report" />
At 12:40 PM a high pressure alarm was activated and the furnaces heating the splitter tower were turned off, and the outtake valve was finally opened. The quick release of liquid that had been heated far beyond normal specifications overloaded the heat in the heat exchange unit causing the liquid going into the tower to be over 150 degrees hotter than normal. Once this liquid mixed in with the already high level of fluid in the splitter tower, it boiled and expanded forcing a rush of flammable liquid hydro-carbons to spill out of the safe-guard release tube, filling up the blow-down drum and causing a "geyser-like" release of flammable liquid hydro-carbons into the atmosphere for about a minute, leaving a large flammable vapor cloud.<ref name="What Went Wrong: Oil Refinery Disaster">{{Citation | last1=Price | first1= Tom |display-authors=1 | title = What Went Wrong: Oil Refinery Disaster | journal = Popular Mechnics | url = http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/gadgets/news/1758242 |month= September | day = 14 | year = 2005 | accessdate= May 1, 2014}}</ref> At 1:20 PM, the cloud was ignited by a diesel pickup truck located about 20 feet from the blow-down drum, causing a series of explosions across the plant as fuel storage units were reached by the growing fire.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report" />
==Aftermath== Immediately after the explosion on March 23, 2005, members of the U.S. Chemical Safety Board (CSB) were on site to determine the root cause of the accident and where blame and responsibility should be placed. In the end, BP was held liable for the event and ordered to pay out over $1.6 Billion to upwards of 1000 different claimants ranging from employees families to neighbors within a mile radius of the plant who had their windows blown out in the explosion.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lisa |last=Baldwin |title=BP Explosion Victims' Relatives Oppose Plea |url=http://www.click2houston.com/news/15210120/detail.html |publisher=Click2Houston.com |date=February 4, 2008 |accessdate=February 4, 2008 }}</ref> The CSB published a scathing review of BP's practices in the United States. BP has since sold both of its largest refineries in Unites States as public pressure to maintain safety standards has led these ventures to become less economical than the UK plant sites.<ref name="BP Troubled Past" /> Also released was a report from former US Secretary of State James Baker that highlighted the flaws and lack of commitment to safety inherent to BP on a company wide scale.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/16/AR2007011600208.html |title=BP Failed on Safety, Report Says |last1=Mufson |first1=Steven |last2= |first2= |date=17 January 2007 |work= |publisher=The Washington Post |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> The trial to settle the fine to be paid by BP generated lots of public interest and was fought by Brent Coon & Associates, culminating in $50 Million being paid by BP in August of 2010.<ref name="BP Troubled Past" />
==Factors Leading to Explosion== Multiple factors worked in tangent to lead to the eventual failures that resulted in the refinery explosion. Such factors included technical failures, human errors, as well as organizational and regulatory failings. In the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board reports, organizational failings such as corporate cost-cutting and failure to invest in safety infrastructure as well as the lack of safety culture were listed as the major contributing factors to the explosion.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report">{{Citation | journal= U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board | title= Investigation Report - Refinery Fire and Explosion and Fire | month= March | day= 23 | year = 2005 | city= BP Texas City | url=http://www.propublica.org/documents/item/csb-final-investigation-report-on-the-bp-texas-city-refinery-explosion | accessdate= May 1, 2014}}</ref> These underlying issues manifested in the technical failures such as the undersized blow down drum which started the cascade leading to the eventual catastrophe.<ref name="BP Report">{{Citation | title= BP Fatal Accident Investigation Report -Isomerization Unit Explosion Final Report | city = Texas City | state = Texas | country= USA | month= December | day = 9 | year = 2005 | chapter= Executive Summary}}</ref>
===Managerial Transitions=== Since BP’s acquisition of Amoco who owned the plant before 1998, there have been five plant manager transitions in the six year leading up to the explosion (1999-2005).<ref name="NYT Boldness">{{Citation | last1=Lyall | first1= Sarah |display-authors=1 | title = In BP’s Record, a History of Boldness and Costly Blunders | journal = New York Times | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/13/business/energy-environment/13bprisk.html |month= July | day = 13 | year = 2010 | accessdate= May 1, 2014}}</ref> This rapid change in management at the plant contributed to a lack of leadership accountability as managers are not held accountable to mishaps after their departure. The lack of leadership accountability in turn led to the lack of safety investments due to managers’ short event horizon and desire to demonstrate ability to comply with lean operation and corporate directives.
===Human Factors=== Human errors also played a major role in the Texas City Refinery explosion. Due to lack of funding and focus on safety, employees were often undertrained and lacked adequate supervision for process startup or changeover. Plant employees at the time had been working 12-hour days for 30 days in a row, often with 2 hour commutes.<ref name="Financial Times">{{Citation | last1= McNulty | first1= Sheila | display-authors=1 | title = Blowdown: how faults at BP led to one of America's worst industrial disasters | journal= Financial Times | url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/510bf8fc-8f05-11db-a7b2-0000779e2340.html?siteedition=intl#axzz30PDOWNIc | month = December | day = 19 | year = 2006 | accessdate = May 1, 2014}}</ref> These employee weaknesses combined and factored into the lack of immediate response to stop the progression of events leading up to the explosion.
===Aging Plant=== [[Image:CSB 080114 BP death Wideview.jpg|right|thumb|Worn condition of ultracracker unit]] Technical issues also contributed to the demise of the refinery. The plant was constructed in 1937 and was 70 years old and dilapidated at the time of explosion. In the 30 years prior to the explosion, which dates before BP acquisition of Amoco, there were already 23 fatalities. A report by an independent auditing agency, the Telos group, cited broken alarms and gauges and outdated and undersized equipment.<ref name="Financial Times" /> After the explosion, the final report by U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board cited a plethora of technical failings such as inadequate pressure relief valves and undersized raffinate towers.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report" /> Geoffrey Gioja, a co-author of the Telo’s group audit, stated 'We have never seen a site where the notion 'I could die today' was so real." A particularly revealing fact of the state of the plant is that workers for a time passed a billboard commemorating two colleagues scalded to death by boiling water in 2004.<ref name="Financial Times" />
===Organizational Failure=== [[Image:BP Logo.svg|right|thumb|80px|BP lacked a culture of safety and accountability]] BP's lack of culture for safety and accountability represented an organizational failure that penetrated through BP's corporate levels. This was particularly evident in the fact that instead of investing in much needed safety renovations, in 1999, senior executives made a 25% cut in fixed costs for the Texas City Refinery.<ref name="CSHI Investigation Report"/> This fixed cost cut exerted financial pressure on managers, making allocation of resource toward much needed safety improvements even more unlikely. BP’s organizational and culture failure also includes the inability to accept fault and constructive criticism. Even after the disaster, BP denied fault for cutting Texas City Refinery costs with the suggestion that the cut was not a "directive" but a "challenge" to achieve desired safety target without compromising profitability.<ref name="NYT Boldness" /> The mentality of the BP executives at the time may best be exemplified by BP exec John Manzoni, who was asked to visit the refinery while on vacation. John Manzoni later commented "we spent the day there -at the cost of a precious day of my leave."<ref name="Financial Times" />
===Lack of Economic Incentives=== [[Image:US-OSHA-Logo.svg|right|thumb|OSHA regulates plant safety]] The plant explosion and BP's lack of safety culture may both be partially explained by the lack of economic incentives for safety. Prior to the explosion, Occupation Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) found what they called 300 "egregious, willful violations", for which OSHA only enforced a maximum fine of $21m.<ref name="Financial Times" /> Considering that BP's yearly revenue was $254b around 2005, the 21 million dollar fine was not a justifiable punishment and was not effective in eliciting improvements on plant safety and safety culture from BP.<ref name="BP Revenue">{{Citation | title=BP Revenue in 2005 | journal=wikinvest : Data Source by NASDAQ, BATS Exchange, SEC and Xignite Inc.| accessdate = May 1, 2014 | url = http://www.wikinvest.com/stock/BP_%28BP%29/Data/Revenue/2005}}</ref> This fine was incidentally also significantly lower than the projected $1bn required for safety improvements, which meant that it was much more economical for BP to pay the fine rather than implementing safety measures.
==Related Incidents== BP has faced intense scrutiny for multiple industrial disasters that have occurred in the past decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/oilandgas/9680589/A-history-of-BPs-US-disasters.html | title=A history of BP's US disasters | publisher=The Telegraph |date=15 November 2012}}</ref> Ongoing criticism of safety measures following the Texas City refinery explosion led to Tony Hayward replacing Lorde Browne as CEO in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6256935.stm | title=BP's Browne to stand down in July | publisher=BBC News |date=12 January 2007}}</ref> However, safety incident investigations have continued to attribute cost cutting and efficiency goals as components of BP industrial disasters.
===Prudhoe Bay Oil Spill=== [[File:PrudhoeBayBPOperations.pdf|thumb|BP Operations in the Prudhoe Bay area]] On March 2, 2006, an estimated 267,000 gallons of crude oil leaked through a corroded pipeline in western Prudhoe Bay, Alaska. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4795866.stm | title=Alaska hit by 'massive' oil spill | publisher=BBC News |date=11 March 2006}}</ref> Members of Congress criticized BP for failing to inspect the pipeline, which had not been checked for corrosion since 1998, and for ignoring other signals that should have raised concerns. A 1992 test detected the presence of calcium in the pipeline but did not raise any concerns about corrosion.<ref>{{cite web| first1= Paul | last1= Davidson | display-authors= 1 | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/industries/energy/2006-09-07-bp-hearing_x.htm | title=Congressmen slam BP executives at Alaskan oil leak hearing | publisher=USA Today |date=7 September 2006}}</ref> BP Alaska pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor count of discharging oil in violation of the U.S. Clean Water Act, but only paid $20 million in fines for knowing neglect of corroding pipelines.<ref>{{cite web| first1= Wesley | last1= Loy | display-authors= 1| url=http://puc.sd.gov/commission/dockets/hydrocarbonpipeline/2007/Hp07-001/webexhibit8.pdf | title=BP fined $20 million for pipeline corrosion| publisher=Anchorage Daily News |date=26 October 2007}}</ref>
===''Deepwater Horizon'' Oil Spill=== [[File:Deepwater Horizon offshore drilling unit on fire 2010.jpg|thumb|left|''Deepwater Horizon'' burning following the explosion]] A gas explosion on April 20, 2010 aboard the BP Deepwater Horizon oil rig claimed 11 lives and discharged an estimated 4.9 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Oil flowed for 87 days until the well was capped on July 15. It is considered the largest marine oil spill disaster in history.<ref name="BP Leak">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/oilandgas/7924009/BP-leak-the-worlds-worst-accidental-oil-spill.html | title=BP leak the world's worst accidental oil spill | publisher=The Telegraph |date=3 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/foia/docs/dwh/fosc_dwh_report.pdf | title=On Scene Coordinator Report ''Deepwater Horizon'' Oil Spill Submitted to the National Response Team | publisher=U.S. Office of Special Counsel |date=September 2011}}</ref>
Numerous investigations investigated the causes of the explosion and resulting spill. Most notably, the U.S. government September 2011 report attributed the majority of blame to BP but also faulted the rig owner Transocean and cement contractor Halliburton, noting financial pressures may have dominated safety concerns and poor communication led to unqualified individuals making decisions in their own company’s best interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/pdf_final/DEEPWATER_ReporttothePresident_FINAL.pdf | title=DEEP WATER: The Gulf Oil Disaster and the Future of Offshore Drilling | publisher=National Commission on the BP ''Deepwater Horizon'' Oil Spill and Offshore Drilling |date=January 2011}}</ref> Transocean was also faulted for providing financial bonuses to workers based on the speed which they completed safety repairs.<ref name="BP Leak" />
Jesse Gagliano, a Halliburton technical adviser, testified that he raised concerns about the high probability of a gas leak in the days before the disaster. He recommended 21 centralizer devices be installed to strengthen the cement wall and prevent leaks. BP ultimately installed 6 – a job that Gagliano and Halliburton approved and documented as having been conducted properly.<ref name="U.S. Report">{{cite web| first1= Robbie | last1= Brown | display-authors=1 | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/25/us/25hearings.html | title=Adviser says he raised concerns to BP on well | publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=24 August 2010}}</ref> While testifying, BP released a statement stating “If Halliburton had significant concerns about its ability to provide a safe and high-quality cement job in the Macondo well, then it had the responsibility and obligation to refuse to perform the job. To do otherwise would have been morally repugnant.”<ref>{{cite web| first1= Joel | last1=Achenbach | first2= David | last2= Hilzenrath | display-authors=1,2 | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/25/AR2010082503361.html | title=Lawyers take center stage in oil spill investigation | publisher=''The Washington Post'' |date=25 August 2010}}</ref>
The U.S. Department of Justice filed suit against BP, claiming “gross negligence and willful misconduct.” BP ultimately paid more than $4.5 billion in fines, the largest of its kind. BP was also banned from seeking new government contracts for “lack of business integrity.”<ref>{{cite web| first1= Steve | last1=Hargreaves | display-authors=1 | url=http://money.cnn.com/2012/11/28/news/economy/bp-ban/ | title=BP banned from federal contracts | publisher=CNN Money |date=28 November 2012}}</ref> The spill also led to the ouster of BP CEO Tony Hayward in July 2010, who was widely condemned for stating “There’s no one who wants this over more than I do, I’d like my life back.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/02/rep-charlie-melancon-call_n_598267.html | title=Rep. Charlie Melancon Calls on BP CEO Tony Hayward to Resign | publisher=The Huffington Post |date=2 June 2010}}</ref>
==Conclusions and Generalizations== Direct causes of industrial disasters are rarely apparent. Less tangible factors, including poor manufacturing cultures, inadequate communication, and emphasis on efficiency over safety can in conjunction precipitate industrial accidents. The U.S. September 2011 Deepwater Horizon report noted “root causes are systematic and, absent significant reform in both industry practices and government policies, might well recur.”<ref name="U.S. Report" /> Economic motivations of commercial corporations frequently compete with safety maintenance, resulting in compromising decisions which save companies' time and money in the short run. Such shortsighted economic incentives may distort professional integrity and ethics and often lead to industrial disasters.
{{BookCat}}
==References== {{reflist}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, YangYanzhi!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:49, 30 April 2014 (UTC)

{{DISPLAYTITLE:
Find out more about Europe:
}} This Wikijunior book is intended for kids but we hope it can be of use for anyone. If you want to read into these topics further visit the [[w:Europe|Europe]] and [[w:European Union|The EU]] pages on Wikipedia. Links for further reading should be added in the individual country pages so that readers can find out more about the capital cities, the language, etc. Young learners can learn more about the following areas in Wikijunior: * Languages of Europe and elsewhere: [[Wikijunior:Languages|Wikijunior Languages]] (a featured book) * Religions of the world: [[Wikijunior:World Religions|Wikijunior World Religions]] * World Heritage Sites: [[Wikijunior:World Heritage Sites|Wikijunior World Heritage Sites]] * Ancient Civilizations: [[Wikijunior:Ancient Civilizations|Wikijunior Ancient Civilizations]] * South America: [[Wikijunior:South America|Wikijunior South America]] * Africa: [[Wikijunior:Africa|Wikijunior Africa]] * Wikijunior Europe (''in German'') [http://de.wikibooks.org/wiki/Wikijunior_Europa Wikijunior Europa] * Wikijunior Europe (''in Romanian'') [http://ro.wikibooks.org/wiki/Wikijunior:Europa Wikijunior Europa] {{Template:WikijuniorEurope}} {{bookcat}}

[[File:Great Auk (Pinguinis impennis) specimen, Kelvingrove, Glasgow - geograph.org.uk - 1108249.jpg|thumbnail|right]] The '''[[w:Great Auk|Great Auk]]''' (''Pinguinus impennis'') was a flightless bird of the [[w:alcid|Auk]] family that became extinct in the mid-19th century. It was the only modern species in the genus [[w:Pinguinus|Pinguinus]], a group of birds that formerly included one other species of flightless giant auk from the Atlantic Ocean region. It bred on rocky, isolated islands with easy access to the ocean and a plentiful food supply, a rarity in nature that provided only a few breeding sites for the auks. When not breeding, the auks spent their time foraging in the waters of the [[w:North Atlantic|North Atlantic]], ranging as far south as northern [[w:Spain|Spain]] and also around the coast of [[w:Canada|Canada]], [[w:Greenland|Greenland]], [[w:Iceland|Iceland]], the [[w:Faroe Islands|Faroe Islands]], [[w:Norway|Norway]], [[w:Ireland|Ireland]], and [[w:Great Britain|Great Britain]][[w:Great Auk|1]]. == Extinction == These birds were defenseless, meaning that they could not protect or save themselves, they were hunted for food and bait in the early 1800s by hunters. There was an enormous amount of Great Auks getting killed by hunters, the birds often being driven up a plank and slaughtered on their way into the hold of a vessel. The last known Great Auks were killed in Eldey Island, Iceland. Many of the Great Auk's eggs were said to have been sold to collectors for as much as £300 also. Since then, many auks and eggs were preserved in museums. A close relative of the Great Auk is the [[Razor Billed Auks]]. == Description == [[File:Wormius' Great Auk.jpg|thumbnail|left]] [[File:Keulemans-GreatAuk.jpg|thumbnail|right]] It basically had black backs, white abdomens (belly up to neck), upright posture, small wings, and a big beak. The Great Auk as standing point is about 75 to 85 centimeters (30 to 33 in) tall and weighing around 5 kilograms (11 lb) as adult birds. The bill (beak) was about 10 - 12 centimeters in appearance also. == Sources == [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/242880/great-auk Britannica - Great Auk]
[http://ivorybill.com/g/greatauk.htm Ivory Bill - Great Auk]
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Auk#Description Wikipedia - Great Auk - Description]
[http://eol.org/pages/1050026/details Eol]
[http://messybeast.com/extinct/great-auk.htm Messy Beast - Great Auk]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:
Facts about Europe
}} The table on this page provides you with a summary of facts for each country in Europe. The name of the country in English and in the official languages of that country are in the first column. The second column shows the area of the country in km2. The third column tells you the country's population. The fourth column shows the population per km2 which is a way of showing how crowded a country is. Kazakhstan's figure is '''6''' meaning there are 6 people per kilometre, the lowest in Europe, meaning Kazakhstan is very uncrowded. Meanwhile, in Monaco, there are 16,236 people per kilometre making Monaco extremely crowded! The fifth column tells you the name of the country's currency. The final column lists the main native languages of that country - either official languages throughout the country of languages which are only official in one region. When figures are updated on this page they should also be updated on the corresponding country page (and vice-versa). {| {{prettytable}} latexfontsize="scriptsize" class="wikitable sortable" |- class="hintergrundfarbe5" !Country - Native Name(s)!!Area [km2]!!Population !Population

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Colin Pye!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:QuiteUnusual|QuiteUnusual]] ([[User talk:QuiteUnusual|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/QuiteUnusual|contribs]]) 09:00, 1 May 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: Discussion of a removed exercise (moved from [Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation https://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation&oldid=934887]).
revision.text:
== Discussion from Talk:Haskell/Solutions/Indentation == I'm confused about one thing: Would the solution to the second exercise be 
  of {a
     ;b
      c
     ;d
  }where
  {a
  ;b
  ;c
  ;do
 {you
  like
 ;the
}}way
 i let {myself
        abuse
       ;these
 }layout rules
or 
  of {a
     ;b
      c
     ;d
  }where
  {a
  ;b
  ;c
  }do
 {you
  like
 ;the
}way
 i let {myself
        abuse
       ;these
 }layout rules
? According to the 3 rules given in the indentation chapter, since do is at the same level as the preceding expression, c, a semicolon should be added instead of a close brace. HOWEVER: 
main = do
  print x
  where
    x = 5
prints 5 (in GHC), whereas 
main = do
  {print x
  ;where
    {x = 5}}
gives "parse error on input `where'" even though where is on the same level of indentation as print x so according to the 3 rules, a semicolon should be inserted. However 
main = do
  {print x
  }where
    {x = 5}}
successfully parses and prints 5. -[[User:Qeny|Qeny]] 11:27, 31 July 2007 (UTC) :Uh-oh. You might have found a bug in my interpretation of the Haskell report. Would you be willing to chase up on it? The informal explanation in [http://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/lexemes.html#sect2.7 Section 2.7] and [http://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/syntax-iso.html#layout Section 9.3] has the more precise rules. If not, please check with the Haskell Café or the #haskell channel. Sorry! -- [[User:Kowey|Kowey]] 12:04, 31 July 2007 (UTC) ::To follow up: I suspect that the relevant snippet is "A close brace is also inserted whenever the syntactic category containing the layout list ends; that is, if an illegal lexeme is encountered at a point where a close brace would be legal, a close brace is inserted.", so maybe there needs to be a fourth informal rule, like "if you see something unexpected, (like 'where'), insert a close brace", but maybe that would have its own share of bugs. (FWIW, the first solution looks more like what I was expecting; on the other hand, for your minimal example, this new fourth rule would explain the second ws to layout translation). Frankly, I don't really know much what I'm talking about and was only interpreting the Haskell Report to the best of my ability. -- [[User:Kowey|Kowey]] 12:09, 31 July 2007 (UTC) :::I think that's exactly what we should be put for the fourth rule, then everything would be okay. I guess the question for the example though, is whether "do" is an illegal lexeme to be in a where list. I would guess that it is, because afaik a where list item always supposed to be like indentifier = expression. And what is a lexeme anyway, are a, b, and c lexemes? I guess they would be legal but invalid 'cause they aren't followed by = something. --[[User:Qeny|Qeny]] 08:28, 1 August 2007 (UTC)

{{Punjabi/Navigation panel|Grammar}}
== ਸੰਬੰਧਕ (Postposition) == Postpositions in Punjabi link nouns, pronouns and phrases to other parts of the sentence in the same way prepositions do in English, the difference being that postpositions follow the noun whereas the prepositions precede it. Some Punjabi postpositions are
*'''ਨੇ''' – ''subject case'' maker of the transitive verb. *'''ਨੂੰ, ਲਈ, ਵਾਸਤੇ, ਹਿਤ''' – ''object'' or ''dative case'' marker for indirect object or the direct object of a transitive verb. *'''ਦਾ, ਦੇ, ਦੀ, ਦੀਆਂ''' – ''locative case'' markers, "of"; agrees with the connected noun/pronoun. *'''ਨਾਲ, ਦੁਆਰਾ, ਰਾਹੀਂ, ਤੋਂ''' - ''agentative case'' markers. *'''ਤੇ, ਉਤੇ, ਕੋਲ, ਲਾਗੇ, ਵਿਖੇ, ਵੱਲ, ਤਕ, ਬਾਰੇ, ਨੇੜੇ''' – ''relational case'' markers. *'''ਤੋਂ''' – ''ablative case'' marker, ''from'' *'''ਏ, ਓ, ਵੇ, ਨੀ''' - ''Vocative case'' markers From a functional standpoint a postposition can be ''complete postposition'', ''incomplete postposition'' or ''mixed postposition''. A ''complete postposition'' can independently act as postposition such as ਦਾ, ਦੇ, ਦੀ, ਨੇ, ਤੋਂ etc. An ''incomplete postposition'' can act as postposition only as a part of postpositional phrase such as ਕੋਲ, ਬਿਨਾ in ਦੇ ਕੋਲ, ਤੋਂ ਬਿਨਾ etc. A ''mixed postposition'' can, either independently or in combination with some other postposition, act as postposition such as ਉਤੇ in ਮੇਜ ਉਤੇ or ਮੇਜ ਦੇ ਉਤੇ etc.
== Inflection of postpositions == Some postpositions inflect(change form) to conform in number, gender or case to the following noun or phrase. For example compare ਸੀਤਾ ਦਾ ਪੈੱਨ with ਰਾਮ ਦੀ ਕਿਤਾਬ. Postposition ਦਾ in the first phrase agrees with ਪੈੱਨ in number and gender, both being singular and masculine. In the second phrase ਦੀ agrees with ਕਿਤਾਬ in number and gender, both being singular and feminine. Now take another example ਮੋਹਨ ਦੀਆਂ ਕਿਤਾਬਾਂ. Here again ਦੀਆਂ agrees with ਕਿਤਾਬਾਂ in number and gender, both being plural and feminine. The rules for change of form of such postpositions are generally the same as applicable to adjectives.
At times a postpositional phrase is used instead of a single postposition. For example phrase ਮੇਜ ਦੇ ਉਪਰ ਕਿਤਾਬ contains postposition ਦੇ ਉਪਰ. In such cases the second part of the composite postposition inflects like a noun, that is there is no concord with the following noun or phrase but the concord is with the following verb. See for example ਮੇਜ਼ ਦੇ ਉੱਪਰੋਂ ਕਿਤਾਬ ਚੁੱਕੀ.
== Uninflected postpositions == Many postpositions do not inflect at all. The postpositions ਨੇ, ਨੂੰ and ਤੋਂ always immediately follow the noun. When ਨੇ and ਨੂੰ succeed certain pronouns they are converted into suffixes like ਮੈਨੂੰ, ਤੈਨੂੰ, ਉਹਨੂੰ, ਉਹਨੇ, ਇਹਨੇ etc. When ਤੋਂ follows some pronouns it becomes ਥੋਂ and results in ablative case form of those pronouns, e.g. ਮੈਥੋਂ, ਤੈਥੋਂ etc.
{{Punjabi/Navigation bottom|Adverb|Conjunction}} {{BookCat}}

Removing "Stewart_Parnell.JPG", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Steinsplitter|Steinsplitter]] because: No license since 2014-05-07. Please read the intro of [[commons:COM:L]], about [[commons:Commons:Essential information|essential i...
revision.text:
{{BookCat}} Kenneth Kendrick is the whistleblower in the 2009 salmonella outbreak from contaminated peanuts. Kendrick disclosed information about factory conditions at the Peanut Corporation of America that prompted the FDA to recall over 3,600 peanut products. ==Background==
From September 2008 to April 2009, a [[w:salmonella|salmonella]] outbreak occurred across 46 states, resulting in 714 illnesses and 9 deaths. The outbreak was first traced back to peanut butter produced in a Georgia facility owned by the [[w:Peanut_Corporation_of_America|Peanut Corporation of America]] (PCA).<ref name="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (2010, May 11). Multistate Outbreak of Salmonella Typhimurium Infections Linked to Peanut Butter, 2008-2009 (Final Update). http://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/typhimurium/update.html</ref> After whistleblowing efforts by Kenneth Kendrick, the outbreak was linked to unsanitary conditions at PCA plants in both Georgia and Texas, resulting in a recall of over 3,600 separate peanut products, including those of large-scale manufacturers such as [[w:Keebler_Company|Keebler]] and [[w:Whole_Foods_Market|Whole Foods]].<ref name = "recall list">U.S. Food and Drug Administration (2009, October 28). Peanut Butter and other Peanut Containing Product Recall List. http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/peanutbutterrecall/index.cfm</ref>
In 2006, Kendrick worked as an assistant manager for the PCA plant in Plainview, Texas. During his four months there, he used the Texas Department of Health anonymous reporting service to cite rat and bird feces contaminating the peanut products, but his concerns were ignored. In 2009, after hearing reports about the Georgia PCA plant, Kendrick decided to publicize his case. Working with the [[w:Government_Accountability_Project|Government Accountability Project]] (GAP) and [[w:STOP_Foodborne_Illness|STOP Foodborne Illness]], Kendrick told his story on Good Morning America.<ref name = "Harris">Harris, D. & Barrett, K. (2009, February 16). Former Manager Says Peanut Plant Complaints Ignored. ABC News. http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=6888169&page=1&singlePage=true</ref> Because of Kendrick's efforts, [[w:Food_and_Drug_Administration|Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) investigators were able to tie salmonella cases to PCA products from both plants, prompting more product recalls.<ref name="Food Integrity Campaign">Food Integrity Campaign (2014). Kenneth Kendrick. http://www.foodwhistleblower.org/the-lifecycle-of-food/the-problems-of-processing/contamination/kenneth-kendrick</ref>
==Case Outcomes== Kendrick has reported many personal repercussions from whistleblowing, stating "Me coming forward has pretty much ruined my life."<ref name="Karnowski">Karnowski, S. (2011, February 11). New Food Safety Law Contains Little-Noticed Whistleblower Protection. The Huffington Post. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/11/food-safety-law-protects-whistleblowers_n_821989.html</ref> His difficulties have have ranged from professional, including being fired from his job in 2009, to personal, including depression and the dissolution of his marriage from the stress of public scrutiny.<ref name= "Food Integrity Campaign"/> Kendrick's experience is similar to that of other whistleblowers, many of whom, according to GAP, are negatively affected despite "putting ethics into practice."<ref name="GAP">Government Accountability Project (2014). The American Whistleblower Tour. http://www.whistleblower.org/american-whistleblower-tour</ref>
Beyond Kendrick, the case had ramifications for PCA. PCA, which had about 300 employees, went bankrupt in February of 2009. They have also been the target of multiple civil suits since the outbreak.<ref name="Brumback">Brumback, K. & Bluestein, G. (2009, February 13). Peanut Copr. Of America Files for Bankruptcy. The Huffington Post. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/02/13/peanut-corp-of-america-fi_n_166841.html</ref> ===Food Safety and Modernization Act=== In early 2011, the FDA's [[w:FDA_Food_Safety_Modernization_Act|Food Safety and Modernization Act]] was signed into law following a series of deadly food-borne illnesses, including the 2009 salmonella outbreak. It was designed to better enable the prevention of food-related illness through easier recalls and mandatory safety standards for both produce and processed foods.<ref name="FSMA">U.S. Food and Drug Administration (2014). FDA Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA). http://www.fda.gov/Food/GuidanceRegulation/FSMA/default.htm</ref> A smaller clause furthers this objective by granting increased protection to whistleblowers. Under the new law, employees are not allowed to be fired or denied promotions for reporting unsafe conditions and the burden of proof shifts from whistleblowers to employers in cases of wrongful termination. Critics have stated the law may lead to general complaints instead of reliable reports of violations; however, this remains to be seen after rules take effect in spring of 2014.<ref name="Karnowski"/> ===Litigation===
Investigations into PCA led to the indictment of four PCA officials in early 2013. After FDA inspections of both PCA plants found unsafe conditions, the [[w:Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation|Federal Bureau of Investigation]] joined the case. Investigators found multiple instances of criminal activity, including obstruction of justice, conspiracy, and fraudulent products introduced to interstate commerce. On multiple occasions, PCA officials falsified safety certificates and sold products after they had tested positive for salmonella. These findings led to 75 counts of indictment, including felony charges, which could give PCA officials up to 20 years in prison.<ref name="Johnson">Johnson, K. & Weise, E. (2013, February 21). Peanut Execs Indicted in Salmonella Outbreak. USA Today. http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/02/21/peanut-corporation-salmonella-indictment/1935673/</ref>
==The Roles of Key Participants==
=== Peanut Corporation of America ===
Founded in 1977, the [[w:Peanut_Corporation_of_America|Peanut Corporation of America]] supplied peanuts, peanut butter, peanut meal, and peanut paste for large snack distributors, including [[w:Kellogg_Company|Kellogg]], [[w:Sara_Lee_Corporation|Sara Lee]], [[w:Little_Debbie#Little_Debbie|Little Debbie]] and others, as well as the government, for schools, disaster relief, and the military.<ref name="The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire">The Washington Post. "The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire". Feb 15, 2009. http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/02/14/AR2009021401758_pf.html</ref> PCA sustained strong profits by buying "the cheapest peanuts they could find"<ref name="The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire"/>, relying on minimum wage labor and cutting costs wherever possible. The CEO and owner of PCA, Stewart Parnell, had grown up in the low-cost peanut industry and ran PCA's three processing facilities in Plainview, Texas; Suffolk, Virginia; and Blakely, Georgia from a converted garage next to his home in Lynchburg, Virginia. The company had a history of food quality issues, repeatedly failing the inspections of prospective buyers and facing a lawsuit in 1990 after regulators found unacceptably high levels of aflatoxin, a toxic mold, in a shipment to the [[w:American_Candy_Company|American Candy Company]]<ref name="The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire"/> PCA officials repeatedly shipped product without waiting for confirmation of salmonella lab results, falsified certificates of analysis, and lied to customers and the regulatory agencies about their test results and quality protocols, even after the nationwide outbreak of salmonella.<ref name “Food Safety”> Goetz, G. “Peanut Corporation of America from Inception to Indictment: A Timeline”. Food Safety News. Feb 22, 2013. http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2013/02/peanut-corporation-of-america-from-inception-to-indictment-a-timeline/</ref> They also failed to register the Texas plant with both national and state regulatory agencies, avoiding routine health inspection and remaining under the radar of government scrutiny.
=== Food and Drug Administration ===
A 1990 [[w:fda|Food and Drug Administration]] inspection revealed that a PCA shipment had been contaminated with [[w:aflatoxin|aflatoxin]], a toxic mold, resulting in a recall and lawsuit. Eleven years later, a Nov 15, 2001 FDA inspection again finds aflatoxins in PCA peanuts, noting “ill-repaired equipment” and other concerns at the plant.> The FDA returned to inspect the Blakely plant in June of 2008 after a Canadian distributer refused a PCA shipment containing metal shipments; however, all concerns were corrected on site.<ref> Harman, B. “Timeline of the Salmonella Outbreak”. ABC News. Feb 10, 2009. http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=6837291&page=1&singlePage=true </ref> <ref> Georgia Department of Agriculture Inspection Report. June 17 2008. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/ORA/ORAElectronicReadingRoom/UCM109862.pdf</ref> In January of 2009, more than four months after the beginning of the salmonella outbreak, the [[w:Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention|CDC]] found a contaminated container of King Nut peanut butter sourced from the Blakely, GA PCA plant and the FDA began their investigation which would eventually expand to all three PCA facilities and revealed PCA’s unlawful and unethical practices. <ref> Harman, B. “Timeline of the Salmonella Outbreak”. ABC News. Feb 10, 2009. http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=6837291&page=1&singlePage=true</ref>
=== State Regulatory Agencies === Critics argue that the PCA salmonella outbreak demonstrates a failure of state regulatory agencies, which play a major role in registering food producers and inspecting facilities.<ref name= “TX editorial”> Dallas News. “Editorial: Sacrificing public safety for business’ sake”. December 26, 2013. http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/editorials/20131226-editorial-sacrificing-public-safety-for-business-sake.ece </ref> Salmonella contaminated products managed to make it to market from both the Georgia and Texas facilities, demonstrating a failure of state regulatory bodies both in the rigor of their inspections and their capacity to keep track of food producers.
====Georgia Department of Agriculture==== The Blakely plant inspections conducted by the Georgia Department of Agriculture (GDA) from 2006 though 2008 (the period when the contaminated products were processed) revealed no major issues at the plant. In fact, Former employees describe the plant as “filthy and nasty” and yet the GDA repeatedly rated the facility as “exceeds expectations/excellent” and “superior”. <ref name= “aib”> AIB International. “Chronology of Events Related to Peanut Products Recall Involving PCA”. Accessed May 4, 2014. https://www.aibonline.org//press/AIBStatement04022009/Chronology.html </ref> <ref name= “LATimes1”> Glanton, D. “Ex-employees tell of 'filthy' conditions at Georgia peanut processing plant”. Feb 7, 2009. http://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/07/nation/na-peanut7 </ref> With approval from the state regulatory agency, PCA continued uninhibited until the FDA investigation forced them to seize operations.
====Texas Department of Health and Department of Agriculture==== The Texas plant, where Kendrick briefly worked, was operating completely under the radar of state regulatory agencies. The Plainview facility received organic certification from the [[w:Texas_Department_of_Agriculture|Texas Department of Agriculture]] but never registered as a food producer with the [[w:Texas_department_of_health|Texas Department of Health]](TDOH). As a result the plant went four years without regulatory inspection. <ref name= “NYT”> Harris, G. “After Tests, Peanut Plant in Texas Is Closed”. Feb 10, 2009. After Tests, Peanut Plant in Texas Is Closed </ref> After the PCA incident the TDOH conducted a statewide investigation and found 355 food producers who also had been operating without the proper licensing in Texas. <ref name=”whistleblower”> Food Integrity Campaign. “Kenneth Kendrick”. Accessed May 4, 2014. http://www.foodwhistleblower.org/the-lifecycle-of-food/the-problems-of-processing/contamination/kenneth-kendrick </ref>
==Ethics Considerations== The PCA salmonella outbreak resulted from a system-wide failure. This US food safety system is a complex network of players aimed at keeping consumers safe from tainted food. Several cognitive biases and other effects contributed to the failure of the system. While many may have been in play, this case exemplifies risk compensation, the bystander effect, and the tuneout effect.
===Risk Compensation=== The consequences or risks from selling salmonella infected peanut butter are obvious: people may be harmed and the company will lose sales and possibly go bankrupt. The purpose of regulation, like the FDA’s, may be viewed as increasing the consequences by imposing further penalties for risk taking. This nudges a company to assume less risk. Yet the more pernicious effect of [[w:Risk_compensation|risk compensation]] is likely present. Risk compensation is a well-accepted theory that when the consequences of behaving riskily are reduced, risky behavior increases. People have some sort of internal risk assessment that is adjusted when the variables change. In the PCA case, because the regulated corporation knew it had the safety net of the regulators, it stopped policing itself as well. The risk to the public of receiving contaminated food wound up close to where it started, and the effectiveness of the regulators in the system was reduced. It can be argued that Kendrick himself displayed risk compensation when he learned [[w:Nestle|Nestlé]] had refused PCA peanuts.<ref name= “Leighton”> Leighton, Paul. “Whistleblowing on Unsafe Food: Ken Kendrick and the Peanut Corporation of America (Part II)”. Accessed May 5, 2014. http://www.paulsjusticepage.com/emu/crm412/412-WhistleblowingResponse2.docx </ref> He assumed other companies would follow Nestlé so that even if he left PCA, the public would be safe.
===Bystander Effect=== When a system has many players, sometimes each player pulls a little less weight than would normally be expected. This is known as the [[w:Bystander_effect|bystander effect]], also known as diffusion of responsibility. In the PCA case, the abundance of regulators (the Texas Department of Health, Texas Department of Agriculture, and FDA) encouraged each to act as a bystander. Each regulator may have assumed the others would pick up the slack. Rather than diffusion of responsibility, this case might have been simple confusion of responsibility. Both would be flaws in the system.
===Tuneout Effect=== Sometimes people have the tendency to pay less attention to warning signs the more frequently they are set off. The tune out effect occurs when cautions of risk become less potent the more they are issued. It is a corollary of [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Diane_Vaughan_and_the_normalization_of_deviance normalization of deviance], which is where deviant behavior becomes more accepted over time. The effect is similar to the tendency of people to rarely treat car alarms as an actual car burglary. False positives can be especially detrimental to the efficacy of a warning system. In the case of PCA however, true positives (warnings of actual health concerns) were treated as false positives and ignored. Over time, the regulators and other bodies may have tuned out the warnings from PCA, including Kendrick's. In the mid 1980s, some companies gave the PCA plants failing grades and refused to do business. In the early 1990s, lawsuits were brought against PCA for toxins in their product, and the FDA was aware.<ref name="The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire">The Washington Post. "The Rise And Fall of A Peanut Empire". Feb 15, 2009. http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/02/14/AR2009021401758_pf.html</ref> Upon inspecting the plant, one owner said “It was just a time bomb waiting to go off, and everybody in the peanut industry in Georgia, Virginia and Texas--they all knew.”<ref name= “Gulfnews”> Gulf News. “Falling for Peanuts”. February 16, 2009. http://gulfnews.com/business/features/falling-for-peanuts-1.51920 </ref> The tune out effect partially explains why although the regulators and PCA knew of the risks, they did nothing, even after Kendrick reported violations the first time, in 2006.
This same effect occurred in other ethics case studies, for instance the [[w:Space_Shuttle_Challenger_disaster|Challenger accident]]. Repeated concerns over the O-rings were raised, but each successful launch reassured executives.<ref>{{cite web | author=Outer Space Universe| title=Remembering the Challenger Shuttle Explosion: A Disaster 25 Years Ago | url=http://www.outerspaceuniverse.org/remembering-challenger-shuttle-explosion-25-years.html | accessdate=January 28, 2011}}</ref> By the tenth launch, the concerns fell on deaf ears; the executives had tuned them out. Similarly, concerns had been raised about PCA in the past, but no one had died of salmonella thus far. By the time Kendrick came along, the regulators were tired of hearing of the risks. Kendrick's concerns had faded to background noise. In these cases, unfortunately, the more the concerns were raised, the more they were tuned out, and the less effect they had.
==Conclusion== A number of cognitive biases probably played a role in the case of PCA and Ken Kendrick. What is the general takeaway from a case of the failure of big system?
With large systems, the effects can be faraway or distant. A small decision by one player can lead to large consequences for others, with many players involved in the propagation. Stewart Parnell decided to ignore a few Salmonella tests and people he did not know died as a result. Cognitive biases played a role in allowing this decision to propagate. With these large systems, subconscious cognitive biases may compound into bigger problems that are not realized until catastrophe strikes. When scaling from individual decision-making to large social structures, these biases deserve extra attention.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Sydney3908!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 16:52, 1 May 2014 (UTC)

Earlier, we discussed how [[../Permutation cipher/]] and [[../Transposition ciphers/]] work for people who know the secret key. Next, we'll discuss how, in some cases, it is possible for a person who only has the ciphertext -- who doesn't know the secret key -- to recover the plaintext.
The frequency distribution of the letters in any transposition or permutation ciphertext is the same as the frequency distribution for plaintext.
== breaking columnar transposition ciphers ==
The frequency distribution of digrams can be used to help break columnar transposition ciphers. <ref> Prof. H. Williams. [http://www.krapp.org/hydra/courses/analysis/2c-Trans.pdf "Transposition Ciphers"]. section "Analysis of columnar transposition ciphers". Retrieved 2014-05-01. </ref>
== breaking double columnar transposition ciphers ==
== breaking turning grille ciphers ==
Turning grilles, also called Fleissner grilles, ...
A guess at some sequence of two or more consecutive holes of the grill in one position of the grill (by a "known word" or an expected common digraph) can be "checked" by seeing if those holes, after the grill is rotated a half-turn, produce reasonable digraph.<ref> Helen Fouché Gaines. [http://books.google.com/books?id=CRLPYrG_LAAC "Cryptanalysis: A Study of Ciphers and Their Solution"]. 1956. section "The Turning Grille". p. 29 to 36. </ref><ref> [http://www.nku.edu/~christensen/Elementary%20Crs%20in%20Cryptanalysis%209%20-%2012.pdf "Elementary Course in Cryptanalysis: Assignment 9: Grille Transposition Ciphers"]. </ref>
== breaking other grille ciphers ==

== Etymology ==
I wish there was something about the etymology of the name "Functor" but I don't know what it is, so I can't write it myself.[[User:Backfromquadrangle|Backfromquadrangle]] ([[User talk:Backfromquadrangle|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Backfromquadrangle|contribs]]) 18:28, 1 May 2014 (UTC)
:It is probably less interesting than you expect :) It's just that the pioneer category theorists, when faced with the problem of naming the implausibly general concepts they had defined, chose to borrow evocative terms from philosophy ("category" from Aristotle and Kant; "functor" from Carnap; "monad" from Leibniz). There is no real technical connection though. [This page http://jeff560.tripod.com/f.html] mentions a few more historical details. --[[User:Duplode|Duplode]] ([[User talk:Duplode|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Duplode|contribs]]) 16:33, 2 May 2014 (UTC)

revision.text:
==George W. Bush and "Enhanced Interrogation Techniques"==
===Background=== On September 11, 2001, 19 hijackers crashed four jetliners into [[w:The Pentagon|the Pentagon]] and [[w:World Trade Center|the World Trade Center]], killing more than 3,000 people in the largest terrorist attack on U.S. soil. In the wake of these terrorist attacks, the Bush administration launched the global war on terror in Afghanistan and Iraq to defeat terrorists and their organizations. Controversy has abounded over his support of so-called [[w:Enhanced interrogations techniques|"enhanced interrogation techniques".]] Many critics view these “enhanced techniques” as torture whereas supporters view these techniques as imperative to national security.
Enhanced interrogation methods include sensory deprivation, prolonged periods in stress positions, sleep deprivation, hypothermia, and waterboarding. Between 2002 and 2003 the [[w:Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] considered these techniques to be legal arguing that terror detainees were not protected by the [[w:Geneva Conventions|Geneva Conventions']] ban on torture.<ref>Previously secret torture memo released [http://edition.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/07/24/cia.torture/index.html?iref=topnews]</ref> Since 2001 approximately 100 detainees, including those held by the CIA, have died during interrogations. Some of these deaths may be linked to torture. <ref>The Bush Administration Homicides [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2009/05/05/how-many-were-tortured-to-death.html]</ref><ref>The suppressed fact: Deaths by U.S. torture [http://www.salon.com/2009/06/30/accountability_7/]</ref> Most of these interrogations have been conducted outside of US legal jurisdiction in [[w:Black site|"black sites,"]] which are secret prisons operated by the CIA, to facilitate the United States’ War on terror.
Critics believe the use of torture could have counterproductive [[w:Military|military]] effects as it can cause captors to resist cooperation and give false information. Following the futile advice can have negative economic consequences, and this use of torture may intensify the enemy combatants will to fight. Scholars have tried to verify the effectiveness of torture with little success. Metin Basoglu, MD, PhD and Professor of [[w:Psychiatrist|psychiatriatry]], explained that, “torture generates intense hatred and desire for vengeance against the perpetrators, radicalizing even ordinary people with no strong political view.”<ref name="Costanzo">The effects and effectiveness of using torture as an interrogation device: Using research to inform the policy debate [http://www.cgu.edu/pdffiles/sbos/costanzo_effects_of_interrogation.pdf]</ref>
Proponents believe the United States is acting within the international treatment guidelines for enemy combatants, and CIA director [[w:George Tenet|George J. Tenet]] has expressed that about one-third of the [[w:Al-Qaeda|Al-Qaeda]] leadership have been captured or eliminated as a direct result of interrogation.<ref name="Priest">U.S. decries abuse but defends interrogations[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/09/AR2006060901356.html]</ref> Among these include [[w:Ramzi bin al-Shibh|Ramzi bin al-Shibh]] a key facilitator for the September 11 attacks and [[w:Omar al-Faruq|Omar al-Faruq]] who led plans to blow up US embassies around Asia.<ref>Detainee Biographies [http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.odni.gov%2Fannouncements%2Fcontent%2FDetaineeBiographies.pdf+&date=2009-08-31]</ref><ref>Al-Qaida: Dead or captured[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/4686228/page/4/#.U2j6kPldUiU]</ref> In addition, the U.S. National Security Council spokesman Sean McCormack articulated that “the United States is treating enemy combatants in U.S. government control, wherever held, humanely and in a manner consistent with the principles of the Third Geneva convention of 1949.”<ref name="Priest">U.S. decries abuse but defends interrogations[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/09/AR2006060901356.html]</ref>
===Decisions===
The Bush administration experienced repeated policy change over the rights of enemy detainees and the use of interrogation techniques. On September 18, 2001, in response to the terrorist attacks, President Bush signed the [[w:Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists|Authorization for Use of Military Force]]. The act gave the president the authority to use necessary and appropriate force against contributors to the attacks. However, the United States Supreme Court case [[w:Hamdi v. Rumsfeld|Hamdi v. Rumsfeld]] limited the power us this act by determining that detainees who are U.S. citizens have the right to due process and to challenge their enemy combatant label. The Bush administration believed that if an individual was caught in arms against the U.S. it is constitution to define them as an enemy combatant without access to the court systems. In response, on October 17, 2006, Bush signed into law the [[w:Military Commissions Act of 2006|Military Commissions Act of 2006]], which allowed the U.S. government to prosecute unlawful enemy combatants by a military tribunal rather than a civilian trial and denies them access to habeas corpus. While it also bars the torture of detainees, it allows the president to determine what constitutes torture. <ref>Military Commissions Act of 2006[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-109s3930es/pdf/BILLS-109s3930es.pdf]</ref> On March 8th, 2008, Bush vetoed legislation that would ban the [[w:CIA|CIA]] from using harsh interrogation methods such as [[w:waterboarding|waterboarding]]<ref>H.R.2082.ENR[http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c110:H.R.2082.ENR:]</ref> saying that "the bill Congress sent me would take away one of the most valuable tools in the [[w: War on Terror|War on Terror]]". Furthermore, he said that, “This is no time for [[w:United States Congress|Congress]] to abandon practices that have a proven track record of keeping America safe,” illustrating how he has prioritized the [[w:Homeland security|security]] of the United States.<ref>Bush vetoes bill banning waterboarding[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/23526436/#.U2j1YuZdVy8]</ref>
A United States survey found that only 25% of Americans believe the use of torture against suspected terrorists can never be justified.<ref>Statistics on torture[http://filipspagnoli.wordpress.com/stats-on-human-rights/statistics-on-torture/#2]</ref> Even with a majority of Americans in support, [[w:George W. Bush|President Bush]] was forced to make the tough decision between national security and the human rights of the detainees. He made the decision to take a very supportive stance on enhanced interrogation, asserting that they do not constitute torture and instead provide critical information to preserving American lives, enough though it may infringe upon human rights.
===A Controversial Legacy===
Controversy still surrounds the efficacy of enhanced interrogation practices in the [[w:War on Terror|War on Terror]], and ultimately, Bush’s decisions on the matter have left a contested legacy. In a 2009 [[w:Gallup|Gallup poll]], 55% of Americans believed the use of harsh interrogation techniques was justified.<ref>Slim majority wants bush era interrogations[http://www.gallup.com/poll/118006/slim-majority-wants-bush-era-interrogations-investigated.aspx]</ref> [[w:Jennifer Daskal|Jennifer Daskal]], senior counterterrorism counsel at [[w:Human Rights Watch|Human Rights Watch]], said Bush "will go down in history as the torture president" for defying Congress and allowing the [[w:Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] to use interrogation techniques "that any reasonable observer would call torture."<ref>Bush vetoes torture ban; interrogation methods 'valuable' tool in war on terror [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/bush-vetoes-torture-ban-interrogation-methods-valuable-tool-war-terror-article-1.287394]</ref> However, supporters credit Bush's counterterrorism policies with preventing another major terrorist attack from occurring post [[w:September 11 attacks|9-11]].
In his memoir, [[w:Decision Points|Decision Points]], published in 2010, Bush considered his biggest accomplishment to be keeping "the country safe amid a real danger"<ref>Bush promotes book in Chicago [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-10-21/news/ct-met-bush-visit-20101021_1_decision-points-book-plastic-bag]</ref> and defended his administration's enhanced interrogation techniques, specifically the [[w:waterboarding|waterboarding]] of [[w:Khalid Sheikh Mohammed|Khalid Sheikh Mohammed]], saying, "I'd do it again to save lives."<ref>Bush's Glib Waterboarding Admission Sparks Outrage[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/11/04/bush-waterboarding-torture-book_n_778817.html]</ref>
Overall, scholars have recognized Bush’s presidency as one of the most consequential; a host of substantive decisions, policies, and events that he presided over includes [[w:No Child Left Behind Act|No Child Left Behind]], [[w:Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], the [[w:Patriot Act|Patriot Act]], the [[w:War on Terror|War on Terror]], [[w:Hurricane Katrina|Hurricane Katrina]], and the [[w:Financial crisis of 2007-08|2008 financial crisis]]. This has led to extreme perceptions of his leadership: A [[w:CNN|CNN]] poll conducted in April of 2013 reveals that 80% of [[w:Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] call Bush’s presidency a success, but only 43% of [[w:Independent (politician)|independents]] calling it a success, and nearly 90% of [[w:Democratic Party|Democrats]] calling it a failure.<ref>CNN Poll: How will history remember George W. Bush?[http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/04/24/cnn-poll-how-will-history-remember-george-w-bush/]</ref> [[w:Princeton University|Princeton University]] scholar Julian Zelizer has called Bush’s presidency a “transformative one”.<ref>Historian tips rethink of Bush presidency[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2010/s3018798.htm]</ref>
==HeLa Cell Line== The [[w:HeLa|HeLa]] cell line was the first [[w:immortalised cell line|immortal cell line]] discovered and is still among the most commonly used. Like other immortal cell lines, such as [[w:A549 cell|A549]], [[w:HEK 293 cell|HEK 293]], and [[w:Jurkat cells|Jurkat]], it has played a role in medical testing and contributed to major breakthroughs. The cell line was derived from the cervical cancer cells of [[w:Henrietta Lacks|Henrietta Lacks]].<ref name="immortal">Skloot, Rebecca (2010). The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks. New York: Crown/Random House. ISBN 978-1-4000-5217-2</ref> She was diagnosed with cancer in 1951 and received radiation therapy at [[w:Johns Hopkins Hospital|Johns Hopkins]]. As was standard procedure in that time period, samples of her healthy tissue and cancerous tissue were taken for comparison.<ref name="unsung">Washington, Harriet "Henrietta Lacks: An Unsung Hero", Emerge Magazine, October 1994</ref> 8 months later, on October 4th, 1951, Henrietta passed away. Physician [[w:George Otto Gey|George Otto Gey]] was given Henrietta Lacks' cell samples and, when he cultured them, he noted the "cells did something they'd never seen before: They could be kept alive and grow."<ref>Claiborne, Ron; Wright IV, Sydney (2010-01-31). "How One Woman's Cells Changed Medicine". ABC World News. Retrieved 2012-08-19.</ref> Due to the genetic abnormality of the cancer cells, they were immune to the [[w:Hayflick Limit|Hayflick Limit]] that made the useful life of cells 3 or 4 days.<ref>Ivanković M, Cukusić A, Gotić I, Skrobot N, Matijasić M, Polancec D, Rubelj I (2007). "Telomerase activity in HeLa cervical carcinoma cell line proliferation". Biogerontology 8 (2): 163–72. doi:10.1007/s10522-006-9043-9. PMID 16955216</ref>
===Controversy=== While [[w:Sampling (medicine)|tissue sampling]] was standard procedure and something she would have consented to as part of her treatment, she did not know what was to become of those cells.<ref name="unsung"></ref> She did not consent to her cells being [[w:Cell culture|cultured]] in perpetuity. Henrietta's descendants settled the property rights with the [[w:National Institutes of Health|National Institutes of Health]] in 2013 for a hand in controlling the future of the line and acknowledgements in scientific papers.<ref>Callaway, Ewen (7 August 2013). "NIH director explains HeLa agreement". Nature. doi:10.1038/nature.2013.13521</ref> The central question surrounds whether a person has [[w:Property|property rights]] to their discarded [[w:Tissue (biology)|biological tissue]]. The issue reached the [[w:Supreme Court of California|Supreme Court of California]] in the case [[w:Moore v. Regents of the University of California|Moore v Regents of the University of California]] in 1990.<ref name="immortal"></ref> The family of John Moore wanted a share of the profits from his cell line, purported to have had a 3 billion dollar commercial value over a six year period. The Court decided that Moore has no property rights to his tissue and issued a statement that the "Court needs to balance between protecting rights of patients and the threat of ‘civil liability’ and the hindering of medical research." <ref>Pannelli, J. Moore v. Regents of University of California Majority Decision. Supreme Court of California, 51 Cal.3d 120 </ref> ====Individual Rights==== Western culture has strong views on the sanctity of the human body, with [[w:Paul the Apostle|Apostle Paul]] and [[w:John Locke|John Locke]], two of the most important philosophers in influencing the western thinking, shaping opinions on the human body and personal rights. Apostle Paul stated in [[w:First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Cor]] 6:19-20 that "Your bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit."<ref>Corinthians, First Epistle to the, "The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia", Ed. James Orr, 1915</ref> John Locke stated that "Every man has a property in his own person. This nobody has a right to, but himself."<ref>Locke, John. Two Treatises of Government. Ed. Peter Laslett. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press (1988), 137</ref> They would contend that Henrietta Lacks has the right to prevent her cells from being immortalized and manipulated. ====Welfare of Society==== The HeLa cell line was crucial in the development of a safe and effective [[w:Polio vaccine|polio vaccine]].<ref name="vac">Batts DW (2010-05-10). "Cancer cells killed Henrietta Lacks – then made her immortal". The Virginian-Pilot. pp. 1, 12–14</ref> Prior to the development of the HeLa cell line, researchers spent more time developing and maintaining short lived cultures than they spent running experiments. [[w:Jonas Salk|Jonas Salk]] was able to get large quantities of robust cells to test his vaccine on, accelerating the process of vaccine creation.<ref name="vac"></ref> The polio vaccine decreased the incidence of [[w:Poliomyelitis|polio]] in America from 21,000 cases in 1952 to 61 cases in 1965, following the introduction of the polio vaccine in 1955.<ref>WHO. (2014, March 1). Poliomyelitis Fact Sheet. Retrieved , from http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs114/en/</ref>
==Consequentialism vs. Deontology== [[w:Consequentialism|Consequentialism]], coined by philosopher [[w:G. E. M. Anscombe|Gertrude E. M. Anscombe]] in 1958, holds that the consequences of one’s conduct are the ultimate basis for any judgment on its rightness or wrongness. In the above cases, one could argue that enhanced interrogation, or the use of HeLa cell line is ethical if there is a net positive gain by society. Many scholars, however, doubt the efficacy of enhanced interrogation practices and cite many negative consequences, such as its effect on the perpetrator and its resulting perception of US foreign policy, lending argument to the unethicality of enhanced interrogation even by consequentialist standards.
Contrasting consequentialism is the idea of [[w:deontology|deontology]], where the rightness or wrongness of an act is judged based on its intrinsic character. With many individuals considering enhanced interrogation as torture, it would be considered highly unethical by deontological ethics. On the other hand, some may believe that the use of discarded biological tissues does not truly wrong an individual, thus deeming our second case as ethical even by deontological standards.
Bush’s decisions to support enhanced interrogation techniques and the use of the HeLa cell line are complex and controversial issues that deal with weighing the human rights of an individual against the welfare of a population. While there is no right answer to these problems, consequentialism and deontology provide two opposing moral frameworks with which to consider their ethicality, and may help a professional in making decisions that strike a balance the between the consequentialist systems that make peoples' lives better versus the deontological morality of those systems.
=References= {{reflist}}
{{BookCat}}
